I highly recommend to stay clear of Sony's line of earbuds because they don't last long especially the money you spend on these and customer support is quite mediocre, even more so when you're out of the warranty window.

I was very patient with these earbuds despite issues from the get go, but now after 15 months the right earbud's battery is almost dead, where battery runs out after 40 mins of use.Overall the earbuds have been very uncomfortable in the ear and for long periods of time would become painful.Sometimes the audio would play in a weird stutter like someone is pausing and playing really fast, but I would disconnect bluetooth and reconnect after a bit to fix it.Sound quality was decent and noise cancellation was good, but none of it matters if these $400 headphones stop working after 1 year. Really annoyed and NOT worth the price.

I am not an audiophile, not exactly, so when I am writing about poor sound quality on an expensive pair of earphones whose major selling feature is meant to be outstanding sound quality, you should pay attention.There is a problem with this particular model: these have a very annoying metal echo, almost like microphone feedback. You can miss it when you listening to music, too much going on there, but listen to anything with spoken voice such as a podcast, or an audiobook, or even a simple phone call, and you will hear it loud and clear. Updating, resetting, changing tips, changing audio source, even changing the audio stream, make no difference. None.The earphones I got had this metal echo on the left earpiece only. It drove me nuts eventually and I asked for a replacement from Sony. Sony's process was painless but took a while. When the new earphones finally arrived SURPRISE! Same problem, same earpiece, no solution. This appears to be an issue others have experienced as well: every product has its bad batches, but two pairs in a row, from different batches and different channels? Well, draw your conclusions.I spent some money on accessories for these earphones, which now I cannot get back, but at the very least I can get rid of the earphones themselves. This is not what I expect from a pair of very expensive quality earphones, especially ones that advertise outstanding sound quality. I can do much better sound-quality-wise from my old $100 pair, which I was trying to retire.It is truly said that this model is so defective, they have a lot of nifty little features and can articulate sound very beautifully. Too bad they failed at their primary function of delivering an outstanding sound quality. Well, no more Sony for me.
Huge problem with battery drain. After 1 year of use the left ear bud can only last 1 hour with all features off. The right ear perfectly fine. Beware of purchase not a good long term purchase

reviewTitle: High pitched squeal on the left earbud.
reviewDescription: These arrived today and when I put them on the first thing I noticed was a high pitched noise, maybe around 15000hz in the left earbud. It's not constant, it turns off when music is played, but turns back on when there isn't anything played. It's faint, but super annoying.The noise cancelling seems decent, maybe equal to the pixel buds pro, and worse than its headphone counterpart.The ambient sound, from the 2 minutes I've tested this earbud doesn't seem too bad; it's better than the pixel buds pro's transparency mode, but in all fairness, the pixel buds transparency mode kinda sounds like you're underwater.The sound quality, from the two songs I've listened to on it, it seems like it has a lot of bass, which is what most people like. It sounds great, and I loved the part that it has no sibilance. It makes music very enjoyable and it a great product...if it weren't for the fact that the left earbuds emit a high pitched sound when nothing is played.Overall, I don't recommend unless you've damaged your hearing enough so that you can't hear above 15khz.Edit: Tried these earbuds again and noticed they don't sound good at all above 60% volume. There's also some weird crackling sound sometimes at high volume, but it could be because of my bluetooth/laptop. I am not sure.

I bought this product in late 2021/early 2022. This is the first Sony audio product I bought in a while. Prior to this I owned a pair or Bose bluetooth earbuds that lasted for over 4 years.The sound of WF is good, not as bassy as Bose but close enough. The battery life is good and I loved the fact that each earbud can be used independently. The connectivity range is mediocre at best, my older Bose earbuds have better range than Sonys.However, my pair had major reliability issues that fixed with hard reset over the year of ownership.The earbuds stopped working after 12+ months of use and wouldn't connect anymore.  Sonys care center tried few ways of resetting it again but it didn't work this time. Since I was in my 13month if ownership, repairs wouldn't be covered under warranty. At 350, these are an expensive pair and am surprised with the reliability issues.

I love them most of the time: Good clear sound, mic works good (my wife can hear me great while I work around heavy equipment) however it has been 34 days since they were delivered to my house & no longer charge. I have tried multiple chargers & nothing worksHope this helps the next person buying them
headphones were great until they randomly died 5 1/2 months after I got them. Stay away as they can't even be repaired due to a parts backlog.

The Sony WF-1000XM4 is something worth looking at and investing to have or trying. I was sceptical at first about getting the earphones, but I was amazed at how good the quality of the earphones was. Here are some of the pros and cons that I have soon discovered:Pros:- Opening from the package, I knew that the package was made with sustainable material and was not that pricey. I love this because I personally think that you do not need an expensive box which is gonna be used once. When you take the earphones out, you wouldn't even bother to do anything anymore with the box.- Inside the box, you will receive the different sizes of ear tips, cable and manual. You would be very surprised at how well they designed the box. Truly top-notch for Sony to be doing this.- One of the most memorable things when I was using this is that you would be surprised at how good the memory foam ear tips are. I went to the gym, took a run and moved a lot, but I have never needed to fix the earphones inside my ear. Amazing right? I have never found something that could fit very well.- The noise cancellation and ambient sound are good features added for the earphone. The noise cancellation is quite good for the very noisy places.- It has adaptive noise cancellation as well. It would cancel the noise as needed.- Sony made such a good app for the earphones though. It definitely spent a lot of R&D on the UI of the app. It was easy to use and very interactive- The touch sensor on the earphones are very adaptive as well. It is very comfortable to play forward, backward and play or stop the music.- Battery life is not bad.- Case has a two clutches for opening. Interesting design!Cons:- The ambient sound feature is not as good as AirPods Pro transparency mode. This is something Sony should definitely take a look at.- The touch sensor is not customisable. This is something Sony should fix so that we can choose the best that works for us.- The design of the earphones is something that Sony has to fix. It does not look super nice compared to many of its competitors. It is sticking out and does not look super good.- The case is pretty big compares to its other competitors. Sony should make the case smaller and easier to bring.Therefore, is this something worth buying and upgrading from your previous earphones? I think the Sony WF-1000XM4 is a good upgrade from your previous earphones. The price point is not that pricey, and all of the features from the earphones are super good. You would not find any earphones that are more comfortable and as fit like this.Cheers! I hope this review helps!

I've had these over 2 months now, and I can say I am very happy with them - except for some drawbacks.Good things:- Sound is great. LDAC's higher quality bandwidth doesn't matter to me as I use Spotify (320kbps) but the lower latency with LDAC is noticeable compared to SBC or AAC.- Quality is good, they don't feel cheap/flimsy.- Noice cancelling is incredible - I was blown away coming from the Galaxy Buds Live. Transparency/ambient mode is good too.- Foam eartips are comfortable, however they do take a few days to get used to. These earbuds hurt in the first 2-3 days of using them until the foam adjusted to my ears.- These earbuds are maintained and updated, they received a software update at the end of February that enabled multi-device connection, meaning I can have them connected to my phone and laptop at the same time.Bad things:- Software is possibly the weirdest thing I have used in my entire life. It's not completely awful, but it's definitely not great, and some stuff is just straight confusing. Why is there a badges system for $400 earbuds?- There is a forced dominant earbud, whichever earbud has playback controls assigned has to be out of the case to use the other earbud. Basically, you can't use either earbud on their own, you need to have the one with playback controls on at all times.- You can't customize the controls themselves. There's only preset profiles (playback, noise cancelling toggle, volume, none) with preset controls. By this I mean you can't set the single/double/triple/hold tap to complete a custom action, you need to select one of Sony's set profiles. This is exceptionally annoying because I don't want the playback control hold tap to be the Google Assistant, I would much rather that be ANC/ambient and free up the right earbud for other controls.- Foam eartips flake really quickly. I clean my earbuds gently once a week with some Whoosh and a microfiber cloth, but prior to that I take off the eartips. So it can't be the cleaning that's wrecking the eartips, it's just basic use, and 2 months of use for some serious flaking is terrible.- Touch controls can get finnicky sometimes.- Earbuds are a little ugly and very bulky, but the leaked photos of the WF-1000XM5 look like they're solving this problem without destroying the unique design.- Case is pretty big by 2023 standards.Overall, they sound great, ANC is great, and they're relatively comfortable, but they REALLY need to improve on the software, tap controls, and the fact that one earbud has to stay enabled for both to work at all times.I can recommend these if you can get past the annoyances I talked about. I generally use one earbud so I can hear most of the world around me, but I might be an outlier, so if you use both earbuds anyway you should be good.I also recommend buying these from Amazon Warehouse Deals as I got mine for nearly half price and they still work/look/sound new.

These are probably above average. With some EQ tweaking you can find the sound that works for, but that's likely with any ear bud. I'm not convinced these are much better if at all than any less expensive alternative. Good build quality and nice case with a good solid magnetic hold. Nice looking design. The app is good. You can now pair 2 devices however there are issues with the transition from one device to the other. When paired to phone and PC, then playing audio from PC, the playback with Pause after a few seconds. Repair with PC occasionally to resolve, not sure. The sound is good and what can be excepted for listening to music and team meeting calls. However I am disappointed with the microphone sound quality. It should be better. Not as good as a headset with a extended out front mic from what I can tell. I'm satisfied.

reviewTitle: Good after EQ and eartip change. Good features. Comfortable.
reviewDescription: This is the best TWS I've heard, but everyone who is using these with stock tips and no EQ and claim sound is good should not be trusted.With stock eartips and no EQ, the sound was disappointing compared to my Liberty 2 Pro. After EQ, sub bass is still not comparable to the Liberty 2 Pro, but everything is tighter and cleaner. Piano and high synth notes sound crisp and clear after EQ and tip change.For ear tips, it must be silicone for sound quality. I used one that came with my Liberty 2 Pro and it turned the XM4 into a new TWS in terms of sound.I only gave 3 stars for sound quality because it is unbalanced out of the box and sub bass is still a bit lacking after EQ, although it is adequate.Regarding EQ, 6.3k and 16k will need to be increased by a lot (or maxed) because stock setting was far too off. The other frequencies are up to preference and I increased 400, 1K, and 2.5K moderately. I ended up with +7 Clear Bass (even if I am not a bass head, bass is still important).After tweaking EQ, there was space and air in between quiet notes that fade and then come back. The EQ responds to your adjustments. It offers less bands, but it responds well to EQ and the bandwidth of the adjusted frequencies is moderate to broad, which is good. If it had parametric EQ, it would be best, but the other competition does not have that either.The volume when adjusted with the XM4's touch control seems to allow for a smaller increment, bypassing android's limitation (does not work on some apps). I don't know if Liberty 3 Pro has this feature, but this is a strong selling point for the XM4 and I hope future Sony products will keep or improve this feature. Most of the old apps that can do this no longer work, so it was surprising to see XM4 can do this out of the box.Fit and comfort were good with both tips, but much better and approximately ten times faster to put on with silicone tips. Compared to the Liberty 2 Pro, the comfort and fit was superior. Liberty 2 Pro relies on a wing tip that applies pressure and pushes the ear tip into your ear canal. However, the XM4 just fits snugly once inserted properly. Note that if you do not know how to fit it, then fit will seem bad.Seal must be tested with the Sony app, which is reliable. I kept running the test until it was clear that it sealed every time I put it on. The ear tip size is specific as a slight change in ear tip size will make the seal easier to lose. Liberty 2 Pro (not LIberty 3 Pro) came with way too many ear tip options, so I was able to find the correct one to use for the XM4.LDAC for XM4 (adjusted to prioritization for sound quality in developer settings and Sony app settings) used on Samsung S10E is far superior to Liberty 2 Pro. But on my laptop, likely on AAC, the sound is much better than LDAC on Samsung S10E. This tells me the player source is more important than the codec, but I have no idea what part of Windows is causing this. Either Windows is good, or Samsung is bad. However, the sound on windows without LDAC is better than the sound from Samsung S10E with LDAC.If your computer or device is newer, you will have bluetooth 5.2, which will be superior to AAC and basically replace aptx-adaptive. given that my laptop already produced better sound with AAC or SBS, it is probably not a big deal. There is a website that lets you listen to bluetooth 5.2 sound quality to compare.Despite all this, even though one can salvage the higher frequencies by cranking them up, I did not like that I could only increase back to acceptable levels within deviation for the price I am paying, so I decided to return the product and buy a more expensive wired IEM instead, as I already have a bluetooth amp/dac. I am somewhat regretting losing the comfort and convenience factor from these, but I can wait for Sony to release a newer TWS, hopefully coming with a more balanced stock sound signature while keeping the other pros. I also hope Sony will have at least a 10mm dynamic driver for their new version and improve the sub bass rumble.As of now, I have returned these and tried the 64audio U12t, ThieAudio V16 Divinity, and ThieAudio Monarch Mk2. I want to return the 64Audio U12t and buy the Sony xm4 again.I heard Samsung tweaked the sound signature on their firmware update and that's a cons if they keep doing that because the EQ settings would need to be changed every time they do this.

reviewTitle: Decent wireless earbuds but not quite living up to the glowing reviews
reviewDescription: I bought these earbuds since they were the almost unanimous choice for all reviews I've read. My previous/other pair of wireless earbuds are Jabra 75t, which are working perfectly fine. I just wanted a pair of upgrades.Based on that fact, most of my review can be taken as compared against the Jabra.The unboxing was a pleasant experience. Everything seems recycled and/or recyclable. Even the plastic casing of the earbuds and of the case felt biodegradable.At first, I struggled with finding a good fit. The memory foam tips seems less suitable to finding and maintaining the seal, comparing to the silicone tips most other earphones and earbuds I've used.Also, memory foam tips are just harder to clean than silicone tips in general.The size of the earbuds are also bigger than most, so they are more noticeable by passer-bys when you wear them. This could be a drawback or a bonus, depending on the situation.Once I was able find the fit, the noise cancellation was excellent.When I switch to ambient sound mode, I found the ambient sound more amplified, and I am able to hear more of the outside world.The earbuds battery, when either mode is on, don't last as long as my Jabra, which is slightly disappointing given the size of the earbuds.But the case's battery has a higher capacity. So long as you can (or willing to) take them off for charging for a short while, these earbuds could last a long time.The app... tries to do a lot, which I don't really enjoy. For example, the adaptive sound control automatically switch between noise canceling and ambient sound modes for you, but it tries to be so smart that it requires location, which I find intrusive for an app controlling a pair of earbuds. It also logs quite a lot of usage data, also concerning to me.And who decided an app for a pair of wireless earbuds need achievements?!All in all, while the sound quality is an upgrade, the fit and comfort are still below my Jabra, especially when I'm exercising. In general, I am using these Sony more, but I always keep the Jabra on hand and still use them at least 1/3 of the time.

reviewTitle: Amazing on AAC, can't say for LDAC
reviewDescription: This is probably the first Amazon review Ive submitted; I don't usually leave product feedback but these were just so nearly perfect I had to leave a few words. I don't have an Android device, and am waiting for an LDAC transmitter still to be delivered so I cannot attest anything on that front. This review will solely be on the device's AAC performance.First of all - I don't know what these other reviewers are hearing, but the NC on these are superior to the WH-1000xm4s; I've done side-by-side tests near a fairly loud HVAC unit, near the street, and with a crying baby and these make what was measured by my ipad pro as 45dB sound like a soft hum, in contrast to the cans that leak a little rumble. With sharp, higher noises as well these were superior; you're still going to hear someone talking directly next to you but from around 5m away my wife has to yell to get my attention. This is probably because of the better passive isolation the in-ear offers over the can form factor. Haven't used them on a flight yet but I expect them to block most everything out. The NC has a bunch of functions, like a "focus on voice" that lets voices passthrough. The "speak to chat" feature is annoying, however, and is best left off especially with the quick transparency mode in the default configuration.One thing to be said for comfort, these earphones take a little breaking in, even after you find the right size buds for your ear. They are the comfiest buds I have ever worn, but only after day 3 or so. Before then I was considering returning them, even though the sound quality on these were better than any buds I have ever owned.The sound quality is just excellent, especially if you use DSEE with AAC. It's not magic, but it seems to smooth out the rough edges without diminishing detail. It does drain battery a little faster however. The AAC audio performance on these are far superior to Airpod Pros, which is to be expected as these sell for twice the price. What's odd is that I think these sound better on AAC than my WHs! Granted, the WHs over wired or on LDAC is on a whole another level but that seems like comparing apples to oranges. Like I said, I haven't been able to test LDAC on these yet but as far as AAC goes (which is what Apple users will be stuck with for the foreseeable future) these sound better to me than the WHs. The controls are somewhat customizable from a select list of presets and you can do almost everything you can on the WHs. Both buds are sensitive to touch and they are somewhat easily triggered, especially when laying down.The one improvement Sony can do is make LDAC more usable. As of right now it's only Android devices or licensed vendors that can transmit in this format. I shouldn't have to jump through hoops like VMing linux or buying a DAC transmitter just to use an audio codec on a device I paid for!Anyways, the AAC is more than sufficient for everyday listening (LDAC is pretty unstable, anyways, depending on the signals in your area) and it sounds amazing. Neutral, crisp, detailed.One more thing: no perceptible audio lag, whether on SBC or AAC when watching video, unlike with the Bose models. On Bose if you have to use SBC or AAC on a non Apple device, videos are nearly unwatchable. These work perfectly with both my PC running Win10 and my LGC1 OLED WebOs for watching video on the SBC codec. My Bose produces all always seem to have a perceptible lag.Get these if you're in the market for buds; I usually have a little buyer's remorse after getting premium equipment, but not with these. The NC, comfort, and audio quality all exceed what I expected from CDN400 earphones.

I bought these based on reviews from several prominent mags and websites. I needed a new pair of buds and intended to get the Sennheiser Momentum 3s, but the sales for them at the time had ended, and the Sonys were still on for $250 CA. To set the stage, I’ve been an audio enthusiast for almost 40 years now. I’ve had systems from Linn, Martin Logan, Sonic Frontiers, Bryston, Mission, Cyrus, Ariston, Roksan, Musical Fidelity, bla bla, etc. I’ve had headphones Grado, B&W, Sennheiser (HD 650s) and others. Hence to say that this isn’t my first audio rodeo. So… These buds sound OK (LDAC codec in use). Sometimes they sound great. Sometimes I struggle to find something good about them. My source is usually Tidal Masters or FLAC hi-res. Bass sometimes sounds taut but it rarely goes deep. Mid range shines. Upper frequencies are often dull. You need to get the EQ going to fix the issues that they shouldn’t have to begin with. This is always an audiophile bad sign. Having said that, my main issue, though, is that they simply don’t go loud enough. This is a common complaint online. If you want to listen at conversational levels, you’ll be fine. If you want to crank Metallica, you will not. So, I bought a pair of Momentum 3s on sale recently from another retailer. The Sennheiser’s both sound much better and go much louder (aptX). The Momentums, fed a proper source, are great headphones. I’m not going to go through all of the audiophile tropes but trust me when I say the Sennheisers sound like real audiophile headphones for a remarkable price. I’ve got cables that are more expensive than these buds. The Sonys have some very cool aspects though. I’d say the noise cancelling is slightly better than the Senns and they are smarter to use. They will automatically offer to pair across multiple devices that you own as soon as you pair them once to any device. They will read your email and texts to you with a press of a button. The Sennheisers have yet to do either. Having said that, if you are an audiophile, get the Sennheisers and don’t look back. This makes me distrust the mags and websites that ever recommended these over the Senns based on sound. Always trust your ears.
I really liked these but I found them really slippery to handle in fact one slipped out of my hand while I was taking it out of the case and went down a storm drain so bye bye money for these

As an average user, I have been using those hearphones for over a year and really like them.The noise cancellation and sounds are good enough that I never noticed any major issue.Battery life is very nice too, as I can go about my day without worrying about them dying on me (I always carry the case around).Controlling them by touch is very easy although it doesn't always respond right away. Moreover, when switching between noise cancelling and regular earbuds, there is about 2 seconds where you barely hear your music.The only (minor) negative points are that if you have issues gripping small item with your fingers, it will be very difficult for you to take them out of the case.Every now and them, when taking them of the case, only one of the earbuds is fully charged (even after a long period of time) while the other one stays around 80-90%.Last thing is that sometimes, left and right earbuds are out of sync and not playing the same sound at the same time. It is easily fixed by putting them back in the case for a few seconds.Overall very good product and would recommend it.

Noise cancelation is great, my one gripe is that the ambient mode is actually to intrusive, the sound that comes through is amplified and drowns out music or podcasts, but with sound canceling on the world just disappears which is what I bought them for so I am very happy. Sound quality is the best I've ever had. I've used many different types of headphones/earbuds but never in this price range and the difference is definitive. I find myself hearing nuances to music I've listened to thousands of times that I've never heard before. Makes old song enjoyable to listen to all over again. I find myself queuing music I haven't listened to in years just to hear the difference and re-experience the joy they brought me all over again. Bluetooth connection depends all upon the device you are using. With my Samsung note 10 plus it never falters and sounds great but I have two different adapters for a pc, one works great and was worth $50 another is patchy and causing intermittent distortion which was worth $20. I also found that the closer you can put the adapter to your earbuds without interference from a desk or wall, the better the connection, so investing in a usb extension from the pc to the adapter so it could sit beside my keyboard was the best thing I ever did. Battery life is great. Have yet to have them die on me and charging is quick even though wireless chargers. All in all very happy with my purchase as these are the first earbuds I've ever bought over $100. They have not disappointed me.

reviewTitle: Update - battery problems. Premium earbuds - except the cheap case
reviewDescription: Update Dec 2022 - there is a known issue with the batteries in these earbuds (just Google it). Although Sony seems to be cooperating with most users to exchange all the defective units...buyer beware as not everyone has been fortunate. Essentially what ends up happening is eventually one of the earbuds' battery will deplete so rapidly ending up with at least a 40% difference between the left and right buds. When this happens, expect 30 mins of playtime max. I would not recommend these until Sony has sorted this out. Apparently there is a firmware update but it still has not rolled out in Canada as of 12/19/22.===Start off with the important bits. These earbuds sound fantastic. I have been on the fence about spending a lot of money on them but after going through several others and always feeling like something was missing I kept coming back to these until I finally picked up a pair.The battery is definitely above average. I get about 7 hours with ANC on. Be warned though, using LDAC, google assistant and ANC will kill your battery. Testing with those settings brought me down to 2.5 hours. Seeing as I am listening to AAC compressed music, I decided to use AAC on the buds and the sound is great. One thing that I don't like is the bud batteries do not wear down evenly. Right seems to use more power than the left. After browsing online it seems this is common in all the units and not defective.They are comfortable but may be a little big if you have smaller ears. I tried to like the foam tips that come with it. I didn't like them so switched to some generic silicone ones I had and they fit perfect now. Why Sony doesn't also include silicone tips the way they did with the last generation (the WF-1000XM3) is beyond me. Honestly they can't cost more than $2 to include and for this price of these, they should come with a lot of tip options.Thankfully the app lets you customize the EQ because many audiophiles will not like the default sound out of the box. Once you balance it out, it sounds fantastic.ANC is good for TWS earbuds. Not as good as the headphone version of these (WH) but way better than any other buds I have tried.My biggest gripe with these is the case. For the price you would expect a premium case. Instead Sony ships a cheap case you'd expect to get with $30 buds instead. It feels cheap and you really notice how Sony cut costs when you open them and the hinge actually wobbles like it could come off at any moment. I cannot believe Sony put such premium buds into such a sub-premium case.To compare, my Jabra Elite 3 buds case feels more premium and they are 25% the price of these.Overall I am happy with these but no 5 star rating mainly due to the cheap case that I am sure is going to break shortly after the warranty expires.PROS:- Great sound once you play with the EQ- Great battery life as long as you stay away from LDAC and other options to enhance the sound- Comfortable even after wearing for 5 hours straight (my ears are not small though)- Great app for customizing but Sony should look into making it a little more user friendlyCONS:- uneven battery wear. The right bud wears down faster than left leaving you with about 15-20% difference when the right one dies-CHEAP case - belongs on a no name dollar store brand, not Sony's premium. It's honestly shocking that Sony allowed this case to be used for the WF1000XM4s. It cheapens the entire experience.

reviewTitle: Good quality but awful battery life after 2 years
reviewDescription: Bought these earbuds in november 2021, sound quality has been amazing and noise cancellation is very good as well.Unfortunately, the battery has gone downhill over the past few months.Battery life now is around 1h before needing to recharge them.This is clearly an issue that happens to lots of people as i've seen lots of them reporting this very same issue.Sony's support is like trying to get through a maze.I am disappointed of this major issue given the pricepoint of these earbuds.

I've had these earbuds just about two years. They've been generally a great product aside from some issues with the foam ear tips. However, having owned three pairs of premium earbuds, I expect the product to be durable if it's going to cost $300+Unfortunately, due to packing in a lot of extras to the charging case for wireless charging (a feature I never used) my earbuds no longer charge unless the case is plugged in.I hope Sony improves product longevity in the future, but for now I'll be going back to a company that starts with a b, as they made my favorite pair of earbuds.

reviewTitle: if you can get them to fit, they work well - but that's a BIG IF
reviewDescription: These buds come with three sizes of foam tips (S/M/L). If you are very very lucky and one of these sizes works for you, you will enjoy these headphones. If you're like me and the provided tips do not fit, then you are in for a very frustrating and expensive game of trial and error.I have tried tips from Comply and Sonicfoam based on reviews and still have not found a tip that provides a perfect air tight seal for my ears. And this is very very important. If you do not get a perfect air tight fit, these ear buds are garbage.  The Sony headphone app comes with a feature to determine quality of fit. You will become very familiar with this app because you will be using it a lot in the first few weeks to understand why your Sony's do not live up to the hype of all the YouTube reviews you watched.I understand Sony has provided tips based on some form of customer ear analysis I suppose and they have determined that the S/M/L tips they included will satisfy the maximum number of customers. Maybe they should post a big warning notice on their site: "Attention! These headphones are fantastic IF you can get them to fit, good luck with that"

First things first, thank you so much to the Amazon customer service they've given me above and beyond help, ok let go back to this product review....shipping is amazing as always, this time the replacent is complete, the sound is good for the price it should be, easy to use app and easy to navigate, pairing wise, had to pair and re-pair my S22 ultra to the Sony about 3 times before I get things going and use it properly and also test the unit itself for sound, great sound the ANC is good, the only not so good thing with this earpiece is when you dial your virtual voicemail it doesn't play through the Bluetooth of the Sony instead it plays on the phone itself, when you think that you paid that much for a product you would think that everything is there for your convenience but not this one, you want to be able to listen to your voicemail in a private manner not like broadcast to everyone beside you correct? Anyways still a good product, would I recommend this to a friend? ( Yes and No ), as it depends on thier usage if they'll use this product same as me and I would just let them know that they can try it themselves cause some people will have different say or review of this product, but overall this product with this amount of price I would say it's ok, again this is base on my experience so far and this is my first Sony product to use, thanks and God bless.

reviewTitle: Good potential but very bad quality build
reviewDescription: If you looked at other 3 stars reviews by disappointed costumers pay attention to what they have to say because I did not and I'm the one who threw 350$ out of the window. I would have paid 150$ for these and still be very disappointed.I have the earbuds for 1 year and 2 months. Warranty for only 1 year and what a strange coincidence, every was really falling apart after exactly 1 year.I play music for more than 30 years. Here the verdict from an audiophile:Pro :- The sound is top notch when it works- Decent ANC far from the best when it worksCons:- Bluetooth often shutting down for no reason and impossible to pair again. You need to make them out of battery which is never good for rechargeable batteries.- Random on/off noise cancelling resulting in constantly changing the sound quality- Battery last at best 5 hours with ANC and at best 7 hours without ANC. After 1 year my left ear buds last only 45 minutes.- Very uncomfortable after 1 hour.- The foam is falling apart after few months making them impossible to wear.Conclusion, cant' believe Sony did this but they did. What frustrated me the most is everyone that I trusted in youtube that reviewed the product was definitely lying. I really wanted to think that I had a bad unit but after reading other honest reviews on amazon I get it. If quality means a lot to you and you think 300$ will get there pass by my friend or at least wait for a new model.

reviewTitle: They were great while they lasted
reviewDescription: The left earpiece is completely drained after 30 mins of use. Since the warranty is for a year, I would have to pay out of pocket to get them fixed by Sony. I already spoke to their representatives, and that's the best they can do. So if you want to spend a few hundred dollars for a product that will last a year, these are for you. Suffice to say, I will not buy any Sony products anymore.

reviewTitle: After less than one year, the battery life is quickly declining. For $280 I expect more.
reviewDescription: I use these for web meetings mostly. For me that's a very important activity. These buds sound excellent and work perfectly, but after less than a year the battery life is quickly declining and I have had to quickly change to wired alternatives in the middle of meetings. For $280 I expect more than 11 months of life.

reviewTitle: Really good earbuds but far from great
reviewDescription: I’ve had this issue with Sony headphones and earbuds, I also have the wh-1000xm4 headphones and the first pair I had were defective, the noise cancelling it good but not amazing, my first pair had a ‘trickle’ sound of water. And these earbuds aren’t much better, I was very impressed with the battery life and the ear tips which are nice but after about a month I’ve learned they come out very easily with the tip staying in your ear. Many times when I pull the earbuds out the tip stays in which is beyond annoying sometimes. The noise cancelling is average, I don’t understand everyone’s love for it, before these I had a pair of Jabra earbuds and they were on par with the Sony earbuds only paying a third of the price. The adaptive sound controls are nice at times but I honestly think these earbuds are over engineered, many times when I take an ear bud out of my ear and put it back in, it Desyncs the audio and there is a constant pause. It sounds like the earbuds are trying to get in sync again but just can’t, only way I’ve found to fix this is putting them back in and taking them out. This happens atleast once a day. I have to say, I like the earbuds but they aren’t very loud, the noise cancelling is alright at best, and the technical issues I’ve faced have not at all been representative of the nearly 500 dollars I paid for them. These are sub par for the price point. I wouldn’t recommend buying these unless you have money you don’t know what to do with

Loved the ear buds out of the box. Excellent noise cancelling and sound quality. I was surprised how good the noise cancelling is even compared to my over ear WH-1000XM4.However, after just over a year the battery in the earbuds would drain after only 1 hour of use. This is a common problem potentially due to a faulty update. Many other users face this issue in online forums. I contacted the manufacturer and they will be replacing the unit due to this.

reviewTitle: Don't be afraid to replace the ear tips
reviewDescription: It is a bit of a story but I hope this helps others if they also experience problems with the OEM memory foam ear tips.First impressions were bad.  So bad that I was right away thinking they need to be returned because I found them unwearable.  I could not get a comfortable fit with the foam ear tips that came with it.  After messing with them for a while I used the Sony headphone app to test all 3 ear tip sizes and it told me which size was best for each ear.  So I then used the app to adjust, test, adjust, test until I got a proper seal according to the app.  Every time I put them on I had to do at least 3 adjust until the app said I had a proper seal.  But it never felt right ... I heard too much outside noise even with ANC on ... and bass was missing --- both are indications of a poor seal.  But it was the best seal I could get with the best fitting tip, and they hurt my ears.They hurt my skin where the foam pressed and they never seemed to seal quite right.  I didn't look forward to using them, and I had to take them out after only about half an hour.  So at this point I was sure I would be returning them.But I had a 10 year old Sony DR-BT160AS wireless headphone so I took the very old and dated tips off them and put them on these XM4 and wow!  They were noticeably sealed properly and comfortable!  I used the app and they were sealed properly according to the app each time I put them on without any messing around.  The bass is noticeably the way the content should be.  And the noise isolation was very good even with the ANC off, and of course much better with the ANC on.I am now quite happy with them.  They are comfortable and sound quite good.  I can wear them as long as any other comfortable fitting ear buds now that I have gotten rid of those foam things.I plan to find some silicone tips that are perhaps more modern with better sound capability, but really, they sound quite good with these 10 - 15 year old silicone tips, and the sound isolation is pretty good.So my suggestion is this:If you find them uncomfortable, or not really blocking outside noise even though the app says they are sealed, then I would strongly suggest trying silicone tips - preferably from another set of ear buds that you know fit right.My other advice is you will need to mess with the sound equalizer and bass.  They sound quite unimpressive and dull in the default settings.  So take the time to adjust the sound to match your preferences.  Mine perked up nicely when I added a little "clear bass" to +3 and added some a small boost to 400 and 1k hz.OK, now about the XM4 ear buds:- They are extremely accurate so you will hear EVERYTHING in a song.  So if you have poor quality MP3 then you will hear that.  Years ago I recorded some old albums to MP3 and they were pretty good but vinyl has some pops and snaps, and they sure do stand out on the MX4.- As you probably read, you can control pause & next song & previous song --- OR --- volume up & volume down.  NOT BOTH.  Disappointing, and I think an error by Sony to not allow both controls at the same time.  My work around is that I have it set to pause & next song & previous song, and I use google assistant to control volume ... and the ear buds hear "hey google" almost every time, so it really is not a problem for me.  So now if I want more volume, then I say "hey google" and then "turn volume up" and it works good, but I still a work around on a bad decision by Sony.- I find "speak to chat" an interesting idea but it is not great.  I prefer to pause and turn on ambient sound to chat, and that way it doesn't constantly cut in and out.  Interesting concept but I think it needs more work to be practical.  The ambient sound turned to highest setting does allow you to talk.- DSEE Extreme (fix losses due to compressing music) seems to work decent but I do find it tires me a bit, so I am leaving it off for now.  Mostly it seems to add too much edge or sharpness.  But I am still getting used to these new earbuds, so later I intend to play with it a little more.Overall, I am very pleased with how they sound.  And that, above all else, is the most important thing.

reviewTitle: Honest Detailed Review from an Audio/Musico-phile from Canada
reviewDescription: I won't faff about and get straight to the point. That's what you're here for:• Packaging - Minimalist and environmentally friendly packaging. Everything is well put together and secure inside a very sturdy box made of recycled materials. Inside the box you have the charging case with the earphones, manuals, USB-C cable and two extra sets of ear tips (small and large. medium is on the earphones).• Setup - I have used previous iterations of the WF and WH series, so I had the app already installed on my phone. I put the earphones on and opened the app and it connected INSTANTLY on Android. The case and earphones are not fully charged, so make sure to charge them first. Once you're all connected, there will be an update downloaded which took me about an hour.• App - I won't say too much and let you explore it yourself. Through the app you will be able to customize the equalizer, sound quality, noise cancelling, touch functions, speak to chat, and see a bunch other features like testing fit and seal. It's a robust app that's easy to navigate and has never failed me.• Fit - This is subjective but I have a few tips that might help you. Take the tips and place them in your ear. Don't worry, they won't get stuck or fall in. The one that you feel fits best is the one you should go with. The better the fit and seal the better the noise cancelling and bass will be. You can also test how good the fit and seal is through the app. Attach the preferred tips to the earphones and lead the speaker into your ear canal. You should feel it going into your ear canal. Next, twist it in an anti-clockwise direction to lock it in place. That's it! Shake your head to confirm that it's in place.• Feel - The earphones themselves are very light with a beautiful smooth matte finish. Same goes for the case, which is also ridiculously compact. It's all high quality finishes and once they're in the ear, you won't really notice them. They also look very appealing and stylish. The ear tips are made of a soft malleable material. Imagine squishing a small marshmallow in between your fingers and you'll get an idea of the texture and feel. A small gripe is that you might feel a little benign irritation over long periods of wearing them. This went away once I changed my tips from small to medium, so try that first.• Sound Quality - This is what you're really here for, and these earphones do not disappoint. I listen to everything from traditional classical to the heaviest of metal and all sorts of avant-garde stuff. I have a few staple albums that I use to test any new set of earphones/headphones because they're immaculately recorded with tons of tiny details. They also run the gamut of popular genres and should give anyone a good idea of what to expect:1) The Prodigy - The Fat of the Land: The bass on these earphones is superb. It's not overbearing or gimmicky. It's balanced and complements the listening experience. It's on full display on songs like Diesel Power and Smack My B**** Up where it really shines without losing any details. Elsewhere, the acid tinged synthesizers really buzz. You can almost tell exactly when Liam is hitting the keys as they reverberate and sustain in your head. It feels like you're in the room listening  as he composes the song.2) Tool - Fear Inoculum: This is an album with a lot of layers and intricate musicianship. Adam Jones's guitar comes alive in your head as you close your eyes and imagine him plucking the guitar strings. It really is that detailed. It's like you're sitting in a concert hall watching the band perform for you. Where the earphones really shine is how well they bring out the intricate details of Danny Carey's drumming. I could hear all sorts of faint cymbals and drums in the background and it just brought a smile across my face. If you like rock/metal music then these earphones won't disappoint.3) Hans Zimmer - Blue Planet 2: Hans Zimmer is so prolific and talented that he is constantly finding ways to add new elements to his music. Violins, oboes, trumpets, pianos are all faithfully realized through the earphones, especially on tacks like Albatross Flight. It's so stunning, detailed and clear that it will ignite your imagination. It's honestly better than actually going to the orchestra.• Connection/Battery - No issues with any dropped Bluetooth connection. I keep noise cancelling and LDAC sound quality on all the time and I get a comfortable 6-8 hours out of one charge. If you use DSEE (only if you have low quality music), then expect half that range. I also didn't experience any bugs or glitches related to the earphones or software.• Noise Cancelling - I've had at least 3 other headphones and earphones from the WH and WF range. The noise cancelling on these earphones is slightly behind it's over the head cousins. But only slightly. I've had them on with no music and had my partner talk to me (standing directly in front of me) and I heard nothing. You will be perfectly fine walking on the streets and won't hear anything, unless a big truck goes right by you. I also tested them while using an electric toothbrush, and I really only heard the vibrations of the motor in my head. Overall, top class industry leading stuff here that leaves rivals in the dust.There you have it. These earphones really impressed me. For me, a new pair of earphones or headphones should make me fall in love with my music collection again. It should bring a smile to my face when I hear details I didn't before. These do exactly that. Yes they are expensive, but they also offer a lot in terms of specs and features. If you want the best, then these are it. I actually sold my Sony headphones because we finally have nearly 20 hours of battery life in a super compact and portable package without any loss of sound quality. That alone is worth the price for me.Best sound setting recommendations:• Noise cancelling on• Bright equalizer preset• Customize the preset with 2 or 3 points of clear bass• Switch to focus on quality over connection• Switch to LDAC codec on Android.

reviewTitle: No real flaws, just a really really good pair of ANC earbuds.
reviewDescription: I am writing this review after having used the Airpods pro and wf100xm3 as my daily drivers for over a year.The noise cancellation is amazing. I have used expensive over-ear headphones that don't even come close to the noise cancellation these pair of earphones offer (mainly compared with the Momentum 3 wireless).I truly can't hear ANYTHING when commuting with low-volume music playing. The transparency mode is good, but nothing contests the Airpods pro transparency mode for me. Still great transparency though, I am just a little spoilt. Most things about the build quality also feel good. The hinge on the case is a little squeaky and not that tight feeling, but the earbuds and the rest of the case feel amazing. Nice matte finish, and quality. The case is definitely chunkier than the Airpods pro case but it doesn't bother me. The XM3 case did definitely bother me. The sound quality is great, really clean sounding with a nice bass. Paired with the noise cancellation it is truly next level. Really nice sounding. Much cleaner and balanced than the Pros and the 1000xm3. The controls are good, but since using the pros, I have never preferred touch controls. The pressure sensor on the pros are just unbelievably good. The controls are top-tier compared to other touch sensor buds, though. I've used the galaxy buds Pro as well as the 1000XM3s but these are by far the most responsive and quick. Comfort is great too, they fit in my ear really well and almost never fall off. The pros fit in my ear unbelievably well but these still fit in my ear great and don't get close to falling out. The XM3s never fit well in my ear and would fall out often. The battery life on these is AMAZING, 8 hours of ANC is truly a luxury. I remember, I woke up, put on the buds, and ate lunch, went to the gym, worked out, went to the library, studied, and went back home, and still had 30% remaining battery. I never took off the buds once. This is truly the biggest difference between the pros and these buds. The battery life is so noticeable and amazingOverall, Sony nailed this. They have everything. Best in class ANC, great comfort, amazing sound, responsive controls, great battery life, great transparency mode, amazing build quality.+ they look pretty stylish. Subjective though xD

These are nice earbuds. The sound quality is exceptional, however there are a couple of annoying things.But first, the fit in the ear is exceptional. You will have to give your head a hard shake for them to come loose. The overall sound quality is fabulous for something so small. Controls are easy to use.The noise cancelling feature is not as effective as I hoped. The Sony WH 1000 XM4 over the ear phones are far more effective at noise cancellation. My old Bose corded noise cancelling earbuds are more effective. However the Sony produces richer sound than the Bose.The sound quality is not as good as Sony WH 1000 XM4 over the ear phones.The other annoying feature that is shared with the Sony over the ear phones. They often drop the volume with a beep for a second or two like they are adjusting for an outside sound, perhaps trying to compensate for intruding sounds. The blip in volume is quite noticeable and seems to happen regularly, especially when wearing these in a noisy environment.Maybe I am nitpicking, but for the price I expected a little better.If size is important then these are a great choice, if you are comfortable with much larger over the ear phones, then the Sony WH1000XM4 is a better choice.One month later…The more I use these earbuds, the more I dislike them. I am convinced there is NO difference between ambient sound and noise cancelling mode. Regardless of mode I can hear quite a bit of background noise. The constant beeping and volume drop is exceedingly annoying. I do not know why it does this. It seemingly happens for no apparent reason and occurs regularly regardless of background noise or silence. Even though the sound is good and the fit it good, I keep going back I my corded Bose noise cancelling earbuds as they perform so much better. The noise cancelling function with the Bose is far superior.  I realize this not comparing apples to apples. I wish I could try the Bose cordless noise cancelling earbuds to compare to the Sony to give a fairer comparison, but they too are expensive items. In retrospect I regret the purchase of the Sony earbuds as they in no way live up to expectations promised by Sony.

I've been an owner of all the Sony noise cancellation Headphones and earbuds and have always been a fan. One thing about Sony's headphones is that they are definitely immersive than any other headphones as you can feel the bass and even the thumping of the guitar within your head as though you were sitting beside the artist whispering soft music directly into your head. No other headphones gives you this immersive experience especially when you compare Apples to oranges. The new WF-1000XM4 case is half the size of the WF-1000XM3 and I guess Sony had been listening since I complained about having to wear oversize pants just to carry their headphones around. The half size case is a delight and it almost feels like a set of AirPods. The new circular type headphones takes some time to get use to as Sony now uses foam tips and to wear foam tips you have to squeeze the tips and quickly insert and twist the tips into your ears. You cannot simply squish the earphones into your ears like you would with the rubber tips. Also there is a high pitch annoying squealing of the headphones as you insert into your ears; no idea probably holding or covering the mics as I insert. I need to form new muscle memory to insert the new headphones. Although the app has adaptive sound control I have never used it mainly because it uses location services which basically turns on GPS which drains your phone. Also I am not a fan of the 360 Reality Audio which is basically an attempt of cloning the features of spatial audio from Apple. Just feed music directly into my brain and I'm happy. 360 Reality Audio just basically puts you into a room with music which isn't really that immersive. I love the new foam tips as they almost seal and cements the headphones into your ear making the headphones as one with your brain and no shaking of your head will dislodge them. I think that with each evolution of Sony's headphones they get better and better and I love my WF-1000XM4 more than the XM3. If you are on the fence about buying the XM4, do jump over. Beats all other headphones hands down!

reviewTitle: Best headphones ever. Sound quality and best noise cancelling
reviewDescription: These headphones are everything they're meant to be.

Full of feature.As an example, you can set it up that if you speak it mute the music so you can talk to people without having to manually touch the ear buds.The bass his perfect. lots of it without being too much.Fits great too.
amazing sound,great bass and very convenient app control!

reviewTitle: Great sound, stood shadow and finish.
reviewDescription: Sound is beautiful. Noise canceling is excellent. Bass is good once tweaked IN THE SONY APP that you'll need to download. The previous version might have a bit stronger bass but listening to both at the same time (left and right ear) is sooo close. Extremely important with these to choose correct sized tips. Very good range. Not good for phone calls as your voice gets tinny and echoing. Great battery life. IMPOSSIBLE!  to pick up or take out of case if you have dry hands. Stupid shape and finish made to feel like cardboard is bad decision. But they sound great! Never get drop outs with S23 Ultra and set to priority on quality. No lag. Unlike the previous version they pair properly with my Sony OLED TV (FINALLY Sony,geez). Actually play LDAC files.

reviewTitle: Perfect Earbuds for Travel and Workout
reviewDescription: I would describe myself as a very picky customer, but this earbuds is absolutely perfect for me.- Travel: the noise cancellation functions as great as those big over-ear headsets, much better than airpods IMO, and my ears don't feel hurt wearing it for 5hr+ flights.- Battery: I've used it for 8 months now, the battery is still perfect, it won't run out before your flight. My flight is often less than 8 hours.- Workout: this earbuds uses memory foam, you need to squeeze the foam first and quickly put it in your ears before the foam stretch back, but so far it's the most stable earbuds than any other sports earbuds. It will stay firm even doing HIIT, which is very amazing. However the downside is that the foam might absorb some sweat, but I wipe it after workout and 8-month use seems pretty clean.- Sound quality: it's only decent, but I don't think you should weight this factor a lot, since 90% of your daily use might be on the go, the other 10% might be calling. If you want good sound quality, you might want to get headsetd instead, as they are naturally better for music and cheaper.

reviewTitle: Did not meet claims, disappointed and returning
reviewDescription: I was looking to replace my Soundcore Life p3 which my family enjoyed so much all of them purchased them too. They used to make it around 7 hours of non-stop battery life but at 1.5 years old, I am only getting about 3 hours from a full charge. So even though I love them, I was hoping for something with a more durable battery, These Sony WF-1000XM4 are advertised as running 8 hours with NC on and a lot of comments claim these are easily the best sounding and NC wireless earbuds they have tried so I wanted to try them.I was really disappointed, there is nothing on them that justifies the price being 3x's as much. Here is what I found:After some tweaking of the EQ I really liked the sound better at low and even mid volumes. But at mid-higher volumes I didn't hear a big sound quality difference, albeit I don't hear as well at my age so my opinion here is possibly skewed. Both seemed to go about the same max volume.I love they would pause the music and turn on ambient mode if I started talking. I also found they stayed in my ears better than my current earbuds but I did notice more soreness after wearing for any length of time. I always wear both earbuds, so although I didn't experience this, I saw some complaints that some features do not work if you are only wearing one earbud so be aware of that if you like to wear one at a time.The noise cancelling is huge disappointment as they paled in comparison. I found the Sony pair did a better job of blocking out voices, but it was horrible in comparison at removing constant noises like fans, vehicle noise, snoring, etc. which is more important to me. The Sony earbuds also do not amplify voices in ambient mode but do amplify wind. The fact it turns on ambient mode (if enabled) when talking, you think it would focus on boosting voices, not traffic/wind noise. My old Soundcore earbuds definitely win in this category.I love that they pause playback when you remove them and they will turn off if you take them out and not put them in the case. However, normally when I take earbuds out, I put them in the case or I know I'll lose them so it is neat feature with very little real benefit.The big deal breaker was battery life. Sony claims these earbuds can go 8 hours with NC turned on. Reviewers were claiming more around 6 hours but that is good for me. So this was the primary reason I purchased them. When they arrived, the earbuds are much larger and heavier so I expected this was quality/battery life. However, from a full charge, the right earbud went dead in just 3 hours even though the left earbud was still at 50%. This repeated after doing another full charge and trying again. Normally, I'd assume this is a defective product and that also means the sound quality, NC, etc could all be off from what I should be experiencing. However, after a google search I found lots of other users having this issue with these Sony earbuds. The red flag is some reviewers had them replaced by warranty only to have the exact same problem with the new earbuds. This issue has been going on for a couple years and I've seen complaints as recent as a few weeks ago. This suggests it is pointless to go through the hassles of warranty claims or even getting a replacement.So I'm hugely disappointed. Buying these on sale for $250, they were more than 3x's expensive than my Life P3 headphones (currently on sale for $80). Considering the sound quality is only noticeably better to me at low volumes, the NC and ambient modes are not nearly as good, the battery life is much less than advertised, and the faulty hardware is an ongoing issue that has been unresolved for at least 2 years, I can't justify keeping these. I've initiated a product return with Amazon and will stick with Soundcore.

Buy something elseFirst pair I bought had one battery die much faster than the other. I got it replaced under warranty, and the brand new one had the same issue. Bought another pair because the batteries are so weak. The third pair also has the same issue.Sony customer service admitted that the audio quality on these plummets because it doesn't have the power to both send audio through the mic AND listen to audio through the same time. In other words, your audio quality on video games and phone calls is awful. You will NEVER hear footsteps in games like COD or Fortnite if the mic is on. You literally need to buy a separate microphone if you want to game with these.It also has bad integration with windows, so you have to adjust a few settings EVERY time you connect the earbuds to a computer for gaming in order to stop the mic from automatically turning on when various apps/programs turn on, thereby ruining the sound qualityThe bluetooth has terrible range and constantly cuts out when you're going for a walk, no matter what settings you adjustAmbient sound turns on every time your mic is turned on, which means you always hear noise the noise around you when you're on a call or gaming with the mic, and there's no setting to turn it off.There's virtually no customization with the touch settings on the earbuds other than the bare minimum.It refuses to connect properly to devices, so you have to disconnect/reconnect the earbuds on a daily basis, usually more often than onceIf you have the setting that allows the earbuds to connect to two devices at once, it will consistently pause whatever is playing on the 2nd device every 3 seconds (not an exaggeration) because it seemingly can't allow two audios to be playing at the same timeThe actual sound, noise cancelling, and ambient noise of these earbuds are good, but only when all the other problems aren't happening, which are constantEven at this moment, I'm on the app for the earbuds trying to make it connect so I can remember all the other problems it has, but it's not connecting, again.

Almost one year after purchase, right bud kept 30 min charge only. 3-400$ for a year of use, I would say these buds do not worth the money.They always were a bad fit, hard to have them in ear, i was originally impressed with features and ANC up to the point in which warranty repair turn me sour on them.I've sent them the buds for warranty and I am waiting and waiting for any back. I am not used with this when I dealt with any other company for warranty repair. Typically I'd expect a refurbished unit to be delivered like next day. Now i am almost 1 month after, still waiting... communication from them is typically non existent unless i call.Sony: I've been a fan , I have/had a few product of yoursBased on the warranty and support: I wish you good luck in the future but I am done.follow up:one star due to warranty and product reliability. After 1 moth of waiting and me calling, i am told product is in short supply and mine may be delivered on January. That is 3-4 months waiting !!! ... or i can have a buy back. I've chosen buy back but even for that i need to wait 4 to 6 weeks for the check to be in mail.Value of buy back will be slightly less than what I've paid but heck... still is something.I doubt i will be buying a sony product any time soon or ever.

I purchased the Sony WF-1000XM4 earbuds with high expectations, given Sony's reputation for quality audio products. However, my experience has been nothing short of disappointing. Within a year of use, I began to notice a significant issue with battery life. One earbud consistently drained faster than the other, leading to an imbalanced and frustrating listening experience.I expected a premium product like this to have reliable performance, especially given the price point. But the battery issue severely impacted the usability of these earbuds. What's more, when I reached out for support, my disappointment only grew. The customer service was lackluster, and the lack of assistance for a product just over a year old was disheartening.It's disconcerting to see such a glaring flaw in a Sony product, and even more so to experience inadequate customer support. I wanted to share my experience to caution potential buyers. If you're considering the WF-1000XM4, be aware of the potential for uneven battery life and the apparent lack of support for issues that may arise. It's not worth the price......

reviewTitle: Unbeatable noise cancelling with one irredeemable flaw
reviewDescription: I am an audiophile and a great fan of Sony products. However, I have no choice but to return these, Sony has disappointed me this time.I still give five stars for noise cancellation, sound quality, and battery life. Indeed, these are good, the ANC works better than all Bose sets I have ever tried without significant pressure on my ears, one slight downside is they aren’t as comfortable as the Bose.Their sound signature is almost the same as the classic XBA-Z5, which I happen to love and own two pairs of. XM4s sound warm and reasonably clear, the soundstage is narrower than Z5, which is not unexpected. After all, they are Bluetooth, single-driver and only sold for half of the price. Adjusting the EQ (7 5 0 7 10 cb+10) helps a lot, but don’t expect a game-changer.The batteries (both the pods and the case) charge reasonably fast and hold longer than advertised. The bamboo-based case is good for the environment.Regardless of the good things, there is one irredeemable flaw you MUST know before buying these, it simply isn’t talked about enough.I bought these mainly for video conferencing. I noticed the left pod makes a metallic echo when I talk, clank my teeth, or even when someone else is talking, as long as ANC is on. This seems to be a common problem (just google “WF1000XM4 metallic”) and cannot be solved by exchanging, so I eventually decided it’s better to simply get WH1000XM5 instead. Sony’s costumer service is friendly but they have no idea what’s going on, don’t waste your time with them.Intriguingly, the same model sold on the Chinese market does not have this issue, I suspect it’s because they don’t come with voice assistant?Think twice before you buy these, they are not exactly cheap. If you can accept the flaw then it can become a good deal after WF1000XM5 comes out, check the current price for XM3 as a reference. For me though, when I pay more than $200 I expect some kind of reliable quality, so that’s a return, hopefully Sony can get its stuff together.

reviewTitle: Got scammed by Sony! Worst purchase ever!!
reviewDescription: Paid $370 to get these in 2022. Worked only for 1 year and few months. Has major issues with battery. Battery drains in 20 minutes and overheats when charging. It is a widespread issue and Sony is aware of this. But they do nothing to fix it. Their solution is to repair it which they say will take 3 months (they know nobody will send it to be repaired if it takes 3 months. It is their way of avoiding the liability). If you don’t have an extra set of earphones, you have none for 3 months. Sony agent agreed to a refund in the chat and they later called and went back on their word. Said the retailer on amazon is not a registered retailer with Sony. As if we have those details before making a purchase decision.So save your money. One year of usage is not worth the price at all.

Volume for the left earbud constantly dims at random. At first I could fix it by physically shaking the earbud a bit, but now it's unresponsive until it inexplicably fixes itself. This isn't an issue with the speaker being clogged or anything, I've checked everything.For such an expensive product, I'd hoped it would have lasted longer. I was shocked to see it hasn't even been 2 years since I've owned it. I've taken great care of it, never dropped, and kept well away from moisture damage. This is unacceptable, no wonder the warranty is only 1 year.

reviewTitle: Battery drain and lack of Sony support
reviewDescription: Look up Sony earbuds battery drain and you'll see how many people have had issues with this. Mine happened just a few months after warranty was up. After contacting Sony and jumping through their customer support hoops, they rejected my proof of purchase and offered repair if and when the parts become available!!Paying over $300 for a consumer product with a life span of just over a year, this is not worth it! I will never buy a similar Sony product including the new WF-1000XM5 one. Overpriced junk!

reviewTitle: Very low quality for the price and started having problems a year in
reviewDescription: DO NOT BUY! Not worth the price!At first, they were working great. Decent sound quality, ok noise cancellation, and great battery life. I could get up to 8 hours at a time. Around 4 months in, the left earbud started making some annoying, short, high-pitched noise every once in a while that was only audible if listening to people speaking (phone calls/online calls/audiobooks/tv shows/movies that do not have any background music). A year in, the left earbud started having trouble charging, and now has a battery life of one hour. I expected significantly better quality out of a Sony branded earbuds that I bought for $300. These things clearly have a terrible build quality, and are not worth the extravagant price. DO NOT BUY!

I purchased these in May of 2022. The headphones were great for the first year, which happens to correspond with the length of the Sony warranty. At around 14 months, I started experience frequent sound quality issues, including static and very broken up audio. I contacted Sony and followed all their trouble shooting tips, which did not resolve the issue. I was then told that it was a hardware issue and I would need to pay for a repair.Absolutely outrageous! I paid nearly $400 for these headphones and they lasted barely over a year. What an absolute joke of a product. DO NOT BUY THESE PIECES OF CRAP. I have another pair of Bose headphones that I use at the gym; had them for 5 years and they still work perfectly, aside from a decreased battery life.I AM NEVER BUYING ANOTHER SONY PRODUCT.

reviewTitle: Battery doesn't last as long as the original buds
reviewDescription: They were fully charged, and hardly gave me 3 hours - while mostly using noise cancellation.  Not as impressed as I thought I should be. As well, when a warning comes through on your phone/tablet that there is only 15% left...that means it is about to die.  You begin to get warning beeps, but at most, get 5 minutes after the 15% warning.  On top of that, the fit isn't fantastic, and have purchased various ear buds that are better overall, including sound. Would not purchase again.

Fit will vary for every individual, but I couldn't get a consistently comfortable and secure fit with these earbuds. When I did manage that, I found that they'd cause pain after a few hours, which doesn't happen with my Galaxy Buds 2 earbuds.I tried Comply foam tips with them, but still couldn't get a secure fit...and still had ear pain. So, I suspect that the shape of the Buds2 Pro just doesn't work for me.

The price is good and they are 100% legit Samsung Buds2 Pro. BUT. I ran into an issue with mine (the ANC would produce a loud, constant white noise) and brought them to the Samsung Experience store. While they confirmed they are legit buds and not clones, they are not the Canadian model and will thus not be supported by any Samsung warranty or repair. According to Samsung, mine were intended for the Lebanese market.
Sound quality is great. I cannot get them to stay in my ears with any one of the 3 sets of tips.
Basss thiek thak

reviewTitle: Product warranty not vaid in india

reviewDescription: Nach den vielen positiven Bewertungen, die ich über die Galaxy Buds Pro 2 gelesen habe, habe ich mich entschlossen, sie selbst zu kaufen.Da ich ein Samsung S22 Ultra habe, gefiel mir die Idee, dank der verschiedenen verfügbaren Integrationen im Ökosystem zu bleiben.Die Ohrstöpsel sind gut gebaut, sie sind Qualität und in meinen kleinen Ohren passen sie sehr bequem. Ich habe zuerst die Firmware aktualisiert und bin dann zum Testen übergegangen!Ich fand sie zu leise, der Bass ist da, aber nicht wirklich und nicht immer und das Hörerlebnis war insgesamt enttäuschend, da es Zeiten gab, in denen alle Frequenzen in Chaos vermischt schien. Es ist gut möglich, dass ich ein fehlerhaftes Paar Kopfhörer bekommen habe, da ich auch ein paar Bluetooth-Unterbrechungen hatte.

Die Geräuschunterdrückung mit intelligentem Abschalten bei einer unterhaltung funktioniert soweit, der sound hat mich bisher auch nicht enttäuscht. Allerdings ist die Bedienungsanleitung, die Garantiekarte und auch die Verpackung nicht auf deutsch. Für die einzelnen Befehle durch antippen muss ich also im internet schauen. Besonders ärgerlich ist, dass die falsche Farbe geliefert wurde. So kurz vor Weihnachten auf so eine linke Nummer zurückzugreifen nur um Verkäufe zu erzielen finde ich unterirdisch.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 2, 2023
reviewDescription: I really wanted to like these headphones. I've had the original samsung buds for a few years and they have been pretty good. Decent enough sound, have survived lots of bike rides in the rain and trips to the gym. I also have the sony wh xm4 headphones which are fantastic noise quality and the anc is great too. I wanted to upgrade my buds by getting some with more up to date sound quality and anc for use in the gym. The wh xm4s are a bit big for gym use and the original buds aren't noise cancelling. I considered the sony wf xm4s and these buds 2 pro. I went for the buds as they are a higher water resistance and read reviews that the wf xm4s were quite large in the ear. The buds looked sleeker. I also have a samsung galaxy s22 plus mobile and only use headphone with my phone. I was hoping they would be an up to date version of my original buds.First impressions were good. The base was good, punchy and the anc was great. I noticed they didn't fit in my ear as securely as the original buds but they didn't feel like they'd fall out. After trying a few songs with them.I noticed that the higher notes of songs such as snares and 's' in vocals were quite sharp and tinny making the listening experience uncomfortable. The overall sound of the buds also wasn't as warm as the sonys I have. The eq options on the samsung app are limited but I did try some 3rd party apps to see if I could get the buds to sound better by lessening the harshness of the treble, but I couldn't and the sound of them was ruining songs that I really liked listening to with my original buds or sonys. It really is a shame and I'm not sure what is causing this issue. There are quite a few other people having the same issues in forums online. I'm returning them and will go back to the drawing board. Maybe wf xm4s or 5s....Edit - went for the sony wf1000xm5s which are perfect. A fair bit more expensive but worth it. No more harsh trebles or high vocals. Great fit, sound and anc. 5* recommend.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
reviewDescription: These are great earbuds. Sound quality is there. You can appreciate The different instruments, and there is no lack of bass. I don't feel my ears getting fatigued from the sound of the buds themselves and that is a big plus. 5/5 given the price in that regard.They're super easy to use and connect, you just have to get used to using the wearables app. I also occasionally use them with my PC via Bluetooth and I can even control the settings on there with the same app.The active noise cancelling gets a 4/5 from me. It works great 90% of the time. The only problems I regularly experience with it are if I skateboarding, it will pick up the wind and play even louder than the wind to try to muffle it. Occasionally plays a loud sound when your hair hits the mic if you have longer hair. Overall good and most people won't have these issues.Finally the last point, fit, and the reason it gets an overall 2/5. These DO NOT like to stay in your ears! They will work themselves out with any movement of your head or jaw. The only time these stay in my ears is if I am lying in bed not doing anything. I longboard a lot(eBoard) and the little vibrations in the rode will work them out of my ears in minutes. Walking/running works them out albeit more slowly. Working out does the same if you do any overhead motions. Chewing any sort of food or snack will walk them out of your ears. Talking on the phone will walk them out of your ears. Seriously, any time I move my head or jaw they slide out just a little bit but enough to be annoying, and then fall out if I do more. 0/5 here.I paid a hundred and twenty on sale, and so the quality for the price was there. I love everything but the fit. I kept them past my return window because I have a lot of other headphones and audio gear, so these rarely get use, and I can put up with them for what they are. Perhaps my ears are just built in a way that causes me this problem, but I have talked to several other people in my daily life who experienced the same thing. 2/5

I've never had ear buds before and thought I should have a pair. I bought a pair if the Sony wf 1000xm4.These were the top of the line buds from Sony, I shouldn't have any issues right? Wrong!  They just wouldn't fit properly. Bulky and they wouldnt fit, As a result the sound also suffered. I just wasn't happy at all with them. So I took them back and started the search again.Long story short ....I tried a pair of Samsung Pro buds 2 and love them! the fit is perfect, noise cancelling is excellent in my opinion, and as  a result the sound is great!!
