I suspect 6 hours will be my limit and I'll have to take them out of my ears for a break. As all of our ears are different? Your mileage may vary. Choosing the right tip and wing is vital.Accessories: It's an efficient setup with a good selection of tips and wings for most users. The charging case is smaller than the previous model which is nice.Battery life: I always recommend charging before 1st use. After 4 hours, I'm still at 65% battery remaining with ANC on. They claim up to 32 hours, with a full charge on the case. Depending on what level of ANC you use and listening volume, your mileage may vary. I suspect that their claims are pretty accurate.Packaging and unboxing: Efficiently excellent. They come in a 6" by 6" square box. It opens like a book, with quick start guide on inside left. The eartips and wings are in the "spine" of the packaging, followed by the headphones in their charging case and a USB C (nice!) charging cable.Device build: Excellent. I was impressed with copper color of the "speakers" (where you install the ear tips) I bought the black model. They have a nice matte finish with a grey/silver casing.Sound quality: (Finally!) Overall, they are excellent and they definitely punch above their weight class. The bass response is tight with the tiniest bit of boominess or muddy sound. I suspect a proper break in or changing the wings or eartips will solve reduce this. The midrange and vocals are impressive to excellent. Vocals are very clear and maybe a tad "bright". The treble is excellent. The highhat cymbal is damn near perfect. The stereo imaging and soundstage is EXCELLENT. You can place the instruments in the room. The depth of sound is excellent as well. You can hear the drummer behind the singer and guitar player to left and right. I used Tidal in Hi Res and used the headphones set up in LDAC mode.I use three songs to evaluate my headphones.Wicked As It Seems from Keith Richards excellent Main Offender album (2022 remaster) Keef records in analog and live in the studio. It keeps the "air" in the music and doesn't reduce the imaging quality.Barbie Dreams by Nicki Minaj. I really am not a fan of rap or modern R/B music. I just listen it to evaluate bass response. This track is where I noticed the slight "boom" in the bass. These tracks are basically made and mixed in a computer. No air in them. If you like this type of music, these headphones are satisfying.One by U2 (Mary Blige/U2 duet) This where the vocals and imaging shine. You can hear the subtlety in the Edge's guitar playing. The drums and bass are right where they need to be. You can hear the scratchiness in Bono's vocals and the sheer perfection of Mary's vocal range.I'll probably move on to some Fleetwood Mac, Phil Collins, and the Rolling Stones for further evaluation. I also like Adele and Imelda May. I expect I'll have the same experience as my 3 reference tracks.  After I do some more varied listening, I'll adjust my rating(s) if necessary.My review is really 4.5 stars. They are not quite a 5 but definitely deserve more than 4 stars.If you're eying Sony XM1004 or Bose Soundsport or Sennheiser equivalents but are struggling with spending $300+? Grab these Liberty 3 Pro headphones. Yes, the Sony and Sennheiser will sound better but not twice as good as these Pro models at half the price.If you're looking at dipping your toes in hi-res music and want a starting point? You can't go wrong with these Liberty 3 Pro headphones. I heartily recommend you use the Soundcore app and take the time to do the firmware updates and do the HearID to match these headphones to your ears and hearing abilities.If you've read this far? What are you waiting for? Get a pair or two....

Since most people don't read entire reviews, I'd better get it out of the way.These are incredible for the price. I listen to dnb, edm, and metal and these are fantastic. Multipoint works perfectly despite what a few others here have said (update firmware?). I use these all day at work with my Windows laptop and my ZFold 4. Install the Soundcore app, pair them to the phone, then turn on "Dual Device Connection" to enable multipoint. Finally, pair them with the laptop. Works exactly like it should.Now, on the to the rest. I also have the Liberty Air 2 that I bought a few years ago. Another great value for sound quality, but unfortunately as it goes with earbuds they simply weren't a suitable work device for me as they were constantly falling out when I walked, talked, chewed or even thought about them and had no ANC so keyboard mashing was horrible on the receiving end. Switched back the good old reliable Apple wired earbuds but the cable broke despite them never leaving the desk. I moved on to some much cheaper buds (Lenovo True Wireless Earbuds) for my work calls and meetings. They stayed put but had the worst connection consistency I've ever seen in a bluetooth device, awful quality control (the right earbud broke in 2 pairs almost instantly), about 3 hours of battery life, and Windows hated them (meeting apps would recognize the mic but would often just ignore them as a playback device) and rather than going insane I decided to move on.So here we are. Decided I wanted something better, and spent far too many hours watching reviews of the Liberty 3 Pro and the Sennheiser and Sony comparables. Look, I'm sure the Sennheiser and Sony sound nice too, but these are just SO good for the price it's almost impossible to justify the others costing twice what these do. If you've read this far you probably realize this review is actually just mostly me complaining about OTHER earbuds so here's the thing... I have nothing bad to say about these, they really are a fantastic deal (currently $150 CAD after sale+coupon). The ANC is excellent, mic quality is more than good enough for work meetings, they come with ton of tips and wings so even I who have had the worst time finding comfortable and secure earbuds have been able to get a perfect fit, battery life is great, the charging pod is about as flat as it can possibly be so very easy to pocket, sound is excellent, great customization in the app for EQ and touch controls (you can even set different controls when using both vs when using a single earbud), and multipoint works great.Anker is really doing a great job in this space

I bought a pair of Soundcore Life Dot2 NC last summer and finally returned them because they had only 4 controls apart from the device. But I needed 6 controls: play/pause, ANC on/off, volume up, volume down, track forward, track reverse. I could only choose 4. I contacted Anker through their email to see if they would implement the 6 controls perhaps through a firmware upgrade. Their service people were very nice. But their response  was that no firmware upgrade. But they may implement this in subsequent products. Ultimately the deal breaker was the poor Call quality. People on the other end of the phone call could not hear me talking at all. Perhaps it was just that pair. They were return shortly after.I do have the Sony MX-1000MR3 among others. They are the best by far. Unfortunately, they are top heavy and could not stay in my ears for long. They can stay in my ears for no more than 5 minutes. They just keep falling off or I have to constantly adjust them.I have the Jaybird Vista 2, winged, but they had no ANC. The passive noise blocking makes it worse. I could hear my own breathing and heart thumps.I tried a few different brands and finally settled for the Jabra Elite 85t. They fit well and stay in my ears even without the wings. But they don't survive some moderate exercise like pushups.So I searched some more and came across many rave reviws about the Soundcore Space A40. But they are not winged. Then I found this Anker Liberty 3 Pro that have everyting I wanted. After much research, I finally decided on them. Now I have them for 2 weeks. I am not disappointed. They are light weight, have as good sound and ANC as my Sony's if not better. Their wings keep them secure in my ears even after 100 pushups and survive moderate aerobic exercise. I have yet tried to run with them. They have the controls. They cost a little more than the Space A40 but way cheaper than the Sony's. They are good value. Highly recommend.

Great sound:High highs, low lows. Vocal is great. Good for podcasts. Very clear.This all is great, when you can keep these in place properly. I have had a couple other cheaper brand eabuds that fit my ear canal better and don't want to eventually fall out. I have tried all their 4 silicone ear pieces, as well at the wings, but cannot get the best fit. Sure, might be my canals, but if you get warm, the silicone tips get slippery and with the weight of the earbud itself, it wants to slide out of the best position and almost come out. The tips are made of a good quality material, this is not an issue, just the combo of weighty earbuds with big batteries + gravity cause them to move out of position a bunch.Batteries:Great. 4.5-5 hrs per charge. I almost exclusively use only one ear bud at a time and love the fact that the battery runs out but I can just pop the other in.Once in a while, you need to pay attention to how the ear buds magnetically clip in. You can feel it click in, but it doesn't sit exactly on the charging pins. Doesn't happen very often, but you can see the lights inside the case under each ear bud light up to notify it is now charging. Handy.Multipoint:Very useful when using 2 phones. Connect through bluetooth and you can hear calls from either phone.Whichever phone/listening device last connected is the one sending notifications to the buds. You can hear all your customized dings and beeps, even when on a call.Sometimes, the ear buds do have a hard time recognizing which phone is the last used. Have had many times where I hit the pause function, talk to someone or listen to something outside the earbud, hit the play function and it doesn't play. Sometimes it takes a minute to register, sometimes the other phone's spotify starts playing.Functions:Finger touching works very well. Work with light gloves on and it registers with them.The ability to change the times you touch the buds for each function is great. In the app, you can change each ear buds functions individually, which is extremely handy.You can do the ear bud canal profile set up when first getting the ear buds. This is nice. Does help a bit.Transparency mode works well enough. A slight static-y sound at first, but you don't even notice it after a few minutes. Can hear  at a slightly lower volume than without.Eartips, when secured in place, are a great noise reduction by themselves. I barely use the noise cancelling.Volume level is great. These can get really loud for both calls and music.Call quality:Call quality is great. Voice is picked up from either ear bud well, even in a noisy environment. Last ear buds were terrible in a shop area with loud machinery, these have no issue with my voice coming through clear and loud enough.Earbud weight:Heavy end of buds out there. Have a tendancy to cause ear fatigue when wearing them all day.If I had the choice, I would buy these again. The only downfall is the weight and how far they stick out of the ear.Love the sound.Call quality/reception is top notch.Hope this helps a little

reviewTitle: The bass has a deep punch, the mids are luscious, and the treble sparkles.
reviewDescription: Recommended by 20 GRAMMY Winning Producers, these earbuds are designed to deliver an exceptional audio experience that will blow you away.The Liberty 3 Pro features ACAA 2.0 technology. This exclusive coaxial dual-driver technology ensures that high and low-frequency sounds are delivered directly to your ears without any interference. The result is a wide soundstage that is incredibly detailed and spacious. The bass has a deep punch, the mids are luscious, and the treble sparkles. Whether you're listening to your favorite tracks or watching a movie, the sound quality is simply outstanding.What sets these earbuds apart from the competition is the personalized noise-cancelling feature. While standard noise canceling adjusts noise based on data, the Liberty 3 Pro takes it a step further. With HearID ANC, these earbuds analyze your ears and level of in-ear pressure to create a tailored profile that optimizes noise reduction. This means that external sounds are reduced to a minimum, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in your music or calls.Comfort is another area where the Liberty 3 Pro excels. The earbuds feature a triple-point ergonomic shape and built-in ear pressure relief, ensuring all-day comfort. Additionally, the package includes four sizes of liquid silicone ear tips and flexible ear wings, allowing you to find the perfect fit. Not only does this provide a strong seal, but it also ensures a secure grip, so you never have to worry about the earbuds falling out.To make sure you're getting the best experience possible, it's important to update the firmware of the Liberty 3 Pro. Before using them for the first time, simply connect to the Soundcore app and update the earbuds' firmware to the latest version. This ensures that you have access to all the latest features and improvements.

These are very well-designed earbuds. They fit nicely and produce beautiful crisp sounds with a lot of useful features and customization. I bought the ma bout a year ago and didn't think of leaving a review until I recently had an issue with the battery charger. I contacted customer service and the experience was outstanding.They responded to my email immediately and provided shipping and instructions. I had a replacement pair the day after I dropped them off. Great company and wonderful earbuds to enjoy. Highly recommend.

These offer a decent rich bass, midrange and crisp highs, very customizable sound options and for hearing loss in my 1 ear the hearing test does help offer a better sound! Choose from 4 sizes of tips and wings.. I didn't opt to use wings as it made the fit a little worse, but it's my preference. I find the touch controls a little too sensitive and wished had more configuration options. But overall I'm impressed with these buds! I bought a pair for myself and my son. We have the same overall opinion but he like the wingtips for fit. I'd recommend  these buds
Good sound, a little tricky to get the exact fit for your ear, but lots of different size tips for a custom fit.

After watching a lot of reviews, especially by “picky” on YouTube, I chose these as my next earbud.  So far I am very happy!  I love the fit and sound.  I love that they connect to two devices at once, this is handy for switching between work communications on the computer and phone calls.  The call quality appears to be really good.  One day I had to boost my ride on lawnmower while on a call with my dad.  He barely noticed that I started my truck, opened the hood, connected the cables to the mower, started the mower and then reversers the process.  It’s sounds too good to be true, but it’s true! The battery life is good.  The price was pretty good. The connection distance is good (I can go downstairs from my office and still stay connected to my PC.  I like the eq app to adjust the sound quality.  My only issue is that occasionally they disconnect from my phone during a call.  This used to happen to my old earbuds too so I’m not sure if it is the earbuds or the phone.  Other than that I am super happy.

I’ve owned the previous version (Liberty 2 pro upgraded version). This updated version is great. Didn’t have to EQ them this time. Previous had too much bass and sibilant highs. Only complaints would be how loud they can get, these don’t seem as loud as my previous pair even on flat EQ and maxed volume. Not sure what they did with the tuning there. Otherwise awesome product, battery life has been excellent, I use them at full volume for a few hours before after work and they seem to last. Looking forward to seeing what they release next.

Many conflicting reviews for this set, lots of hype and lots of hate in the Amazon comments too. . Decided to give them a try, could always return them if they don’tlive up to expectations…Here my personal experience with themConnection: pairs flawlessly with IOS, OS and Android. Used them at home, outside and at work, where I left my phone in the office and could still talk or listen to music 75 feet away. I have experienced no loss of signal or hickups in either environment.Fit and comfort: lot of options to dress the buds with the right tips and rings. Rings can be a pain to set properly on the buds but once you got the good ones on you’re set. Initially I was feeling that no combination was giving me a good seal. Then I realized the fit was so smooth and unobtrusive that you almost don’t feel you’re eating them. Those really don’t put pressure on the ear canal, leaving the impression they’re about to fall off but they’re stuck in there tight. They are a bit chunky but they hit a sweet spot of comfort for me.Soundcore app and HearID: personalized sound is a bit strong on the highs but you can always tune it manually to your liking. Audio test made me realize I don’t have the same hearing capacity in my right and left ear. Having each channel tuned to its ear makes a big difference as with other buds, I’m always pushing on the right side bud to make a better seal in order to have a balanced sound. EQ is average but does what it’s supposed to. Presets are gimmicky but you might find one you enjoy.ANC: Probably not the strongest  but works fine. On the positive side, I find it doesn’t cause much fatigue like others. I realize it was on once I turn it off and the urban jungle noise comes back.Transparency mode: it kinda sucks…very high pitched and un-natural. Don’t really need that anyways.Wind reduction feature: there is quite some delay for it to turn on and you need to turn your head in the wind direction for each bud to catch the wind. Don’t expect it to block a quick blow but it should work fine for a steady windy situation once both buds have activated.Phone calls : good on my end, had no complaints on the other end. Didn’t buy these for phone calls so I’ll take them as they come.Music, finally : once you set up the EQ to your liking, these are pretty damn good for the price. Don’t expect 500$ sound, don’t expect reference critical listening. But for casual music on the go, they are very enjoyable. They definitely have a sound signature and EQ can only do so much to compensate. They can get very loud but you can still have a good listening experience at moderate volume, witch I appreciate. Soundstage and detail isn’t on par with good old quality ear cans but  it’s surprising for such a small package and especially for 159$.The evil hiss : lots of people rant about these buds hissing. In my experience of steaming tracks from Spotify, I found some tracks hiss and some don’t.  With the hissing tracks, I switched to a few other buds and the hiss is still audible.  It’s more noticeable on the Liberties as they are very clear on the highs but I don’t find a particular hiss coming from the buds themselves.Overall, Anker makes a good “no-mame” style product. You’d pay a lot more to get the same features from big name brands. I’ve had positive experience with the Anker customer service in the past so I’m comfortable with my purchase in the long run.

I purchase these ear-buds when I look at the reviews and also at who made those reviews.I am rather picky when it is time to choose audio components. And I find very frustrating to not be able to ear in ear phones before the purchase, making this purchase a leap $200 Cdn worth. And on top of these hesitations, I probably bought some 5 or 6 headphones before finding what I consider good sounding headphones. Not to mention that I can't afford $1,000 headphones.The criteria that lead me to these Soundcore ear-buds was the fact that they come with 4 different sizes of ear-buds cushions. I got several ear-buds that were part of some smart phone purchases and I never was able to fit them properly in my ears. Out of the (fancy) box, I pick the third size and these did the trick of correctly sealing the ear canal delivering an astonishing sound quality.I downloaded the app and began to fiddle with a lot of set-ups that at some point could be very confusing. There are more than “20 Sound Effects” setting which are actually EQ settings one can pick from. I tried all of them and was back to the default "Soundcore setting". Which was already beyond my expectations. All these setting were too much of bass, or lack of middle, or lack of presence...Then I notice that there is a LDAC setting available (that unfortunately Apple does not support). This isn’t an Eq setting, but that was the one setting. The surround effect isn't available with this codec but I didn't like those effects... Finally I finished with the personal EQ setting almost flat except for a very small dip in  the treble 12.8KHz (-1 on a range of ±6).The other nice thing (if you are patient to go through these settings) is that each of the two ear buds can be set to:Either raise or lower the volume,Pause / play,Next/ Previous song,depending of you Tap /Hold on  or /Maintain your finger on the right or left ear separately.Conclusion: As far as can I tell, these are in a class apart. I you buy these, you probably will get much more you bargain for. After a charge in their cradle and a software update they will already give you more than a good sound. If you have an hour or two to spend (and some patience) with the app, you should be able to get a very impressive sound.There are still some features (that have nothing to do with the sound quality) that I will have to fiddle with that with to explore. Like the ear sound test and ambient sound feed through, phone call handling...If sound quality is your first criteria, these are for you.Denis from Canada

Am I the only one here who likes these better than the Sony XM4? I had problem with the Sonys, they would not stay in my ears very well and had a microphone feedback problem on the left earpiece. And it wasn't just a one-off defect either.Well, the Liberty 3 Pros stay in my ears pretty firmly, are lighter and comfortable enough to wear for an extended period of time, and also have a pretty decent sound, once configured right. I find that these articulate sound almost as well as the Sonys, but there is no microphone feedback. The noise cancellation is present and working, but it is very subtle and fairly toned down compared to the one on the Sonys. But then the Sonys overdid it and had the feedback problem as a result. ANC on around-the-ear headsets is a life saver and something I am looking for there, but in my experience earbuds are better off with just a very good ear canal seal. This is good enough to not interfere and still help somewhat.I love that the Soundcore app allowed me to reconfigure the buttons the way I want them, but that's about it. Other than this none of the features there to "improve" the sound quite work right. The 3D sound mode makes my favourite artists sound like they are singing in the shower, and also boost the highs to the point the headphones begin to distort. This feature is not meaningful without some controls there. The HearID just cranked all but 2 bands to max for some reason and thus failed to produce a measurable result. Wasn't this just supposed to boost the bands my ears are not as sensitive to? Also none of the equalizer presets quite seem to balance the sound correctly: either too much or too little. Eventually I took over the equalizer myself and now I can enjoy some really nice balanced music with deep lows, articulated highs, and mids that don't overwhelm. I don't think I would be using it much beyond the initial setup. Come ooooon, Anker, do it right!I hate touch controls: they trigger when they shouldn't, do things I never intended to, usually at most unfortunate times when I can't fix them immediately. These have a big flat area so the problems are somewhat less than usual, but I still prefer Anker would just put physical buttons there. I don't understand this touch control trend, it never works well, not even on the Sonys.

Love these, sound is amazing, can quality is great, very good battery life.However, sometimes my left earbud does not charge in the case (cannot figure out why) so I have to fiddle with it until it does.Real disappointment when I start my commute and the left earbud's battery is depleted and I just have to put them away and hope that it charges. Pretty rare but very frustrating when it happens.

I like everything about it except the fit. It comes with a ton of ear pieces but i must be shaped weird as my jabra fit perfectly and these would never last going for a jog, even after trying every combination of earpieces. I use them in the house nowhere where they would fall out and get lost. Love the sound, hate the fit. if these could have a lovechild with my jabra i would be in heaven.

reviewTitle: Excellent for music and calls, but...
reviewDescription: These earbuds are great in all aspects for me except 2 very annoying factors.1) sound cuts out for a second or so pretty frequently. It's so annoying. I've tried everything. Updated firmware, reset earbuds, disconnect forget and re-pair, restart phone, but nothing will fix it. I have a pixel 5 fully updated so that shouldn't be the issue. I've read a lot of people on other forums experiencing same issue.2) the silicone earpieces keep inverting like and umbrella in the wind every single time I pull them out of my ears. So I have to take a few seconds to fix them before I put them in the case. I try to avoid contaminating my earpieces but this makes me need to touch them every time. Since I'm OCD I always wash my hands before I take them out, which is also very annoying.Really want to love these but those 2 points make it difficult to do so.
Sound is really good as expected from Soundcore.

They fit very well in the ear - I do jogging and they stay put. Very comfortable fit. Noise cancellation is mediocre but it's just a nice to have. I got them for music, and for that they are quite good. A bit heavy on the bass sometimes, but very clear (not muddy) and easy to listen to. I haven't been able to get a satisfactory EQ manually, but there are many presets. Actually had the same EQ thing with the soundcore flare - setting it manually never sounded right. Soundstage is big - wouldn't say wide, but spacious and for me that's a big plus. And the length of the charge is also very good. Overall I'm very satisfied.

reviewTitle: Good ear buds for the price!
reviewDescription: Fantastic ear buds for the price.

reviewTitle: Not bad for the money, but disappointed by the ANC performance
reviewDescription: Year after year, I buy a new pair of Soundcore earbuds, from the Air2, Air2Pro, now the 3Pro. Anker does make decent products and I like them for that. However, after watching lots of Youtube reviews of the 3Pro, I was hyped up for the supposedly Sony/Bose-level ANC performance, I was a bit disappointed.... One reviewer even say 3Pro is better than Sony WF-1000XM4 in terms of ANC?!!?....some say it's soooo good it blocks out vacuum and lawn mower...etc. I didn't trust them completely but those videos still gave me high hopes on the 3Pro ANC performance.....and unfortunately my expectations were not met...The sound quality is indeed very good.... might be the best in this class. However, it's the ANC that I'm after; I'm still debating if they are worth keeping. For now, its ANC is good enough as I don't need to commute to work. When I do need to start taking subway and buses to work, I will probably just get a pair of Sony XM4.--Update:Call quality is not good compared to the Air 2 Pro. When people are talking, there is a loud hissing noise. Also people say that they can't hear me clearly. Never experienced these issue with my Air 2 Pro.--Update 2:After a few firmware updates the call quality seems to be improved. The hissing is still there though. I've grown to like these a lot despite the ANC performance is disappointing, simply because the sound quality is just amazing.

reviewTitle: Good enough for every penny you paid
reviewDescription: Pros1. Anc is practical. Cancel out around 80% of env noise2. Multipoint connection is very convenient3. More comfortable than liberty 2 pro4. Soundcore app has many controls of the earbudsCons1. Easily interfered by other wireless devices? Unstable connections especially when connecting with 2 devices. Was connecting with both the laptop and mobile phone at the same time. When playing music via spotify on the laptop, the music paused for less than 0.5 second and then resume automatically. It happened once per 2-3 mins. This was quite annoying that I couldn't finish a song without interruption. The connection seems better in single device connection mode.2. Minor distortion to sound quality when anc is on3. (after 6 months of use) the battery life dropped significantly for the case. Recentyl, i fully charged the earbuds with the case. I took the earbuds out to until it has 10% juice left. I put it back to the case for recharge. The battery indicators of the case dropped from 3 led to 1 led the next day.4. Sometimes one of the earbuds didnt charge while sitting the case. Not sure why it happened. It might due to misalignment, despite it is supposed to sit right on the contact points as guided by the magnet.When it is paired with laptop, somehow windows seems to mute the earbud in some specific conditions. I can't unmute it in Google Meet or through the Windows sound setting easily. It said my earbuds were muted by the system. I have to go deep in the device properties to unmute it. I don't think that is a hardware problem. It may be a compatibility issue with windows.The cons are acceptable given many useful features offered by the earbud at this price. Plus, the built quality is very good.

Bought it bc of the hyper on this page and tbh, kinda disappointed.I do not have lots others to compare with. I went from the 1st gen of Bose wireless to these bc my bose no longer hold enough power for a work-out.pros:1. sound is good, but not wow in anyway. but given these are new, they are expected to get better over use.2. noise cancellation is okay but could be a bit stronger.3. batter life seems fine so far.cons:1. took me FOREVER to find the good sized plugs and wings for my ears. and evetuanlly none fits i settled for the closest, this never happened with my BOse which always sit nicely in my ears.2. there is no volume adjust, or last track.3. most annoying thing is, the touch is so insensitive, everytime i have to pause or next track, I have to tap many times heavily, I might as well smash my ears with a block of brick...overall, you get what you pay for. for half the price of my Bose, they are fine.

reviewTitle: They don't stay in my ears well
reviewDescription: The audio is great. I had other Anker earbuds and loved them but these lock into a different part of my ear and don't stay in place well, especially when sweaty.

reviewTitle: Good sound, average fit quality, bad battery life
reviewDescription: These earbuds sound great, but they fit badly and the battery is very poor: It lasts 3.5-4h only with noise cancelling on and volume at 50%.

I was really hoping to like these earbuds, and for the most part I do. My only issue with them is the battery life. To start I was able to watch two movies (4hrs) over Bluetooth. In the three months that I've had them that has gone down to less than one movie. (1.5-2hrs) Far less than the 8hrs stated. It's to the point where I don't bother using them as its more of a pain to keep connecting earbuds over and over again. Everything else is very good. But based on the battery alone, I wouldn't recommend.

reviewTitle: They're OK but I wouldn't buy them again.
reviewDescription: First of all, I bought these earbuds because of how much I liked my Life A1's that had bit the dust. These earbuds are by no means bad, but I have had a lot of issues surrounding the fit of the earbud in particular. I have tried every tip and wing combination, and none of them allow for a good fit, which makes the noise-cancelling redundant.The touch controls also have trouble registering any multi-taps, meaning that you might end up defining yourself when you try to pause your music.Bluetooth also seems to have some issues with these earbuds. I occasionally have the sound completely drop off for a few seconds before coming back. It is different than a pause/play. The audio will get quieter, become distorted, stop, and then return. I have never had this problem with any of my other Bluetooth devices.Occasionally, when I put my earbuds in their case, they stay connected to my phone, significantly draining their battery overnight.My last gripe is the design of the case. I need to manually wiggle the earbuds in the case to make sure they're charging. I have numerous times now taken them out on a walk after they were in the case and the case was charging, only to get a low battery warning 10 min into the walk.Now that I've written all of my complaints out like this, I don't think I can recommend these in good faith before these issues are addressed. If you can afford  premium wireless earbuds go for the Sony WF-1000mx4 or get a lower end pair of soundcore earbuds. They actually have an excellent price to performance ratio.

I care mostly about sound quality, afterall I bought the PI7's which basically have nothing going for them except for that. The liberty pros (both 2 and 3) have surprisingly really good fidelity for the price, so much so that I don't feel the need to put my Pi7's in to enjoy music. That being said these actually feel cheaper than the Liberty 2 pro's, both the case and the buds themselves feel like a step back. You do get ANC (arguably a non-factor due to it being negligible difference) and an LDAC mode, although unless you use FLAC/WAV you most likely won't notice that much at all. I can also compare these to the Sony WF-C500's, and well, I don't think there's anyone who would prefer the C500's over the Liberty's, even the Liberty 2's are better in seemingly every category imo.If you want sound quality over all the features but your budget can't quite hit the $250+ range then I don't think there's much else out there that can rival the Liberty 3 Pro's, possibly the XM3's but I can't comment on those.For reference: I have experience with headphones ranging from $100-1500 (SE215, Westone W60, Hifiman HE-500, etc.) When I speak of audio quality I want a reference like sound signature with all the frequencies being represented, a good sound stage is a close secondary element. I listen to a bit of everything with experimental EDM, hip-hop, Latin, and classical being the top genres.

reviewTitle: I prefer Anker's A1 Life Earbuds over those!
reviewDescription: I prefer Anker's A1 Life Earbuds over those!Although, The build quality is high and sound is good.What grinds my gears is that Anker's Liberty 3 pro always fall out of my ears too easily. I've tried alot of different rubber fitting that came with the earbuds, but nothing's doing it. Don't even think on gnawing gum or eating, they will fall out your ears instantly. Sporty people, don't even think about it, they'll most likely fall down if you jump or run.From time to time bluetooth signal to my computer "chops" out (only for like a second, still annoying), and with my other earbuds it does not.The charging station isn't that great, they can easily miss-connect and when you get them next day, they're still dead.For half the price get Anker's A1 Life, or even cheap-o earbuds like Flybuds 3...

reviewTitle: Overall not a major improvement over the version 2
reviewDescription: Cons:Couple of issues with Bluetooth not being able to connect to the Earbuds.Noise cancellation works good for low frequencies but not so much for high ones.The EarID test takes much longer than the test for the liberty air pro 2 and doesn't give as good results as it's predecessor. I found myself adjusting the EarID curve a lot.In the input configuration, you can set a control that let's you toggle between the different ANC modes: transparent, normal, ANC. The only problem is that you can't set one earbud to toggle between normal and ANC and the other side to normal and ANC. Both side will use the same configuration.The earbud is able to detect when you put them on, however it doesn't deactivate the input on the earbuds if you don't wear them. So it makes it really annoying when you put them on because you often trigger the buttons while doing so.Pro:Crisp sound once you adjust them a little bitComfortable with the large range of customization tips and ear wingsRange is pretty decent.tl;drOverall for the price, I'm not too impressed given that there are better options in the same price range.
pairing good . But need more Bass..Noisy cancelation  not ok another line still hear all .

reviewTitle: Happy at last. Update: Jan 2023 disappointed... Update May 2023 more disappointment.
reviewDescription: May 2023:The Pro 3's still sound good but they still are a hit / miss whether they'll be charged or not when I take them out of the case. 1/2 the time one is almost dead and I can't use them until I put them back into the case for charging.I ended up buying some SoundCore A40's in the hopes that this model would be better, have now started doing the same thing and both models will most of the time, only charge to 90%.Although I really enjoy the sound of both of these, I'm losing my confidence and find myself looking at other buds so that I can enjoy some consistency.Jan 2023I absolutely loved these buds. They fit me well, the sound is excellent and the quality of the build: awesome. I had expected to use them for a long time.I used them mostly at home at not all that much as I have 2 other Soundcore buds: Life Dot 2 NC for working out and a set of Liberty Air 2 that I use for work and other calls as the mics are incredible.I've been putting up with the dreaded 90% charge: they won't charge to 100% plus, the right bud sporadically won't charge while left in the case. Instead of charging, the battery drains down to almost nothing in the right bud. And I don't find this out until I go to use it.Unfortunealy, the warranty is over and although they've not been used much, they're no longer useable.I like the other soundcore buds I have and the Motion Boom as well ( best small portable player I've ever owned ) so much that I'm going to buy the Space A40 buds and hope for the best with them.I have other IE buds and a Sony WH1000-MX3 currently. I've gone through mid-priced headphones and buds and have either accepted that the sound is okay, like SkullCandy for working out at the gym. Or, great ANC and sound like the Sony's but uncomfortable after an hour or so due to the too-soft padding on the ear cups, for my head anyway.Let me say, those YouTube videos saying how great the Liberty Pro 3's are...are absolutely right.  I am blown away with how fantastic they sound for me!I like strong, detailed bass. Even in rock or metal, I want to hear the kick drums rumble, the bass lines clear and strong.  The Sony's did that for me and the Soundcore's don't have the sound that the bigger drivers of the over-ears.But the sound is so close: the bass is defined and present: I can almost feel it! And at first the highs were a bit too much for my liking but just as on my other Soundcore IE's, the app allows me to tune / EQ any way that I want to.And, I can wear them for hours with no discomfort: they're that good.  The first buds or headphones I've ever had that are just that easy to wear.One of my best purchases, ever.

I will start by saying I did not buy these from watching influencers hype them up. I bought them because I thought the Soundcore Liberty 2 Pro's had potential and wanted to see if the 3 Pro's were the "home run" upgrade I was hoping they would be.To sum it up shortly, they were not an upgrade. If anything, they were a big downgrade.The first thing I noticed when using these is that the soundstage is horribly small.Imagine the speakers in a movie theater. Nice and immersive, right? Then compare them to one of those mini Bluetooth speakers you can fit in your pocket.When you use the Liberty 3 Pro's, it sounds like you're listening to that mini Bluetooth speaker and the soundstage is tiny and not immersive whatsoever. If you have any experience with mid-range headphones, or even just better wireless earbuds, then you'll absolutely hate how tiny the soundstage sounds.Very disappointing and the Liberty 2 Pro's had a better soundstage by far.The second thing I noticed was that there's always white noise in the background when you're not playing any music. The Liberty 2 Pro's had the same problem with constant background white noise (they reduced it with firmware updates, but could never totally get rid of it), so it seems that they couldn't figure out what was causing it and fix it for the Liberty 3 Pro's.Again, pretty disappointing.The noise cancelling is decent, but it's just "decent". If you have any experience with the noise cancelling kings like the Sony WF-1000XM4 and Apple Airpods Pro, then these will not impress you whatsoever.The audio is fine aside from the tiny soundstage. They emphasize the bass and treble a lot, but you can EQ the audio from the app so that's not a problem as long as you can ignore the tiny soundstage.I like the fact that you can fully customize single/double/triple press and long press for the touch controls on both earbuds. This is the one thing about Soundcore which I really appreciate.I like the earbud case and how it slides open because it's cool, but the magnet holding the earbuds appears to be too weak because the earbuds sometimes don't snap into place properly (causing them to not charge properly). I saw a review mention this and thought they were overexaggerating, but the magnets really do seem too weak.For reference, I didn't have this problem with the Liberty 2 Pro's charging case.ConclusionIn my opinion, anyone who wants to give Soundcore a try should probably get the Liberty 2 Pro instead of the Liberty 3 Pro. Even then, I would recommend anyone who sees this review to look around at other companies instead.If you're here for the noise cancelling, I recommend the Sony WF-1000XM4's for Android users and the Apple Airpod Pros for Apple users.If you're here for high quality audio, unfortunately, it's personal preference so you really just have to try everything to know whether you like something or not.

After seeing all the raving reviews about these earbuds online, I was excited for my new pair. Unfortunately, they have not met my expectations. I have been using them for a little over a month now. It really is a shame how many negatives I've experienced with these because I really do love how they sound. Below is a list of my pros and cons:Pros:-Sound great, have good volume, and I appreciate the ability to change the sound to your liking.-They fit and stay in my ear fairly well once I found the right combination of tip and wing.-ANC works decent. Definitely doesn't cancel out all noise but it does reduce outside noise quite a bit. About what I expected at this price point.-Transparency mode also works decent but don't expect to be able to hold a conversation with music playing unless it is at a low volume.Cons:-They aren't the most comfortable earbuds. Even with the proper tip and wing combo, it doesn't take long for them to irritate my ears. Also beware that if you wear too big of a fit, they may temporarily damage your ears. After trying to find my right fit, I had to wait about 2 days before I could wear them again because my ears hurt so badly.-No manual power off. This means that if you are changing your tips/wings or interacting with them in any way out of your ears, you keep triggering the functions.-Functions very often don't work properly or at all. The most common issue is that ANC or transparency mode will only turn on/off in one ear. Sometimes the functions will acknowledge your interaction but won't perform their function.-ANC and transparency mode will turn themselves on/off without any kind of interaction.-Connection issues happen at least once on most listening sessions.-Can be a bit difficult to get the earbuds to properly sit in their case to turn off and charge.-Earbuds will sometimes stay on and connected to your device after being placed in the case and indicating that they are properly seated.-They will sometimes randomly pause my media with no interaction.-Wing tips don't stay in place. As a result they fall out of your ears more easily and cover the in-ear sensor.In conclusion, while I do love the sound, I just can't get over the disappointment and frustration. They might work for someone else, but I wouldn't personally recommend them to anyone.

reviewTitle: Decent sound, mic needs better sound filtering
reviewDescription: UPDATE! I ordered a new pair, thinking the first set was defective. And they were wrapped in plastic, whereas the previous box was not! So 100% the last set was USED and SOLD AS NEW! Very disappointing, Amazon!!I really wanted to like these. I've had other Anker products that were great, I loved the colour, and the reviews were pretty good.I've been using Galaxy Buds+ for a few years and while they're really consistent for connection, and pretty comfortable to wear, they don't have multi-pairing and the sound quality isn't great. Because they're the best I've found so far, that's my baseline.On the Pros side, they had decent sound quality and lots of fit options, so there's a better chance something will work for you. I like that they have multi-pairing, and a variety of options for optimal fit.Cons...I think I received a defective set. Even fresh off the charger, they read 90% charge from my laptop and phone. Also, the mic doesn't sound the same as the sound test I heard online from an independent reviews site, so maybe something's wrong with mine.The mic was ok on Zoom (recording test) in a silent room, as well as with a video playing subway sounds on a speaker nearby. Granted, Zoom does its own sound filtering, so that's more a test of Zoom's capabilities than the microphone's.When I tested the mic by recording a message in my voicemail system, the sound was ok in a quiet room but quickly got overwhelmed by the ambient noise test. In contrast, my Galaxy Buds+ were loud and clear and filtered out the background noise.If Zoom in a quiet room is all you need the microphone for, these will be fine. But if you live in an urban environment with traffic noise and people speaking nearby, they won't be usable for phone calls.

reviewTitle: Amazing sound, but problems pairing and awkward case interior
reviewDescription: Hands down, the very best sound I've ever had in a pair of earbuds. Rich creamy bass and excellent noise cancellation. I could not hear my family talking in the same room as me with ANC turned on, nor any noises outside. Not sure how they would fare against power tools, but for my purposes it was stunning.Ultimately, I returned them, however. For 3 reasons:1. the earbuds had to be re-paired all of the time. I had them paired with my phone, computer, and tv. As long as I changed connection (or kept connected) to 2 devices, all was good. As soon as I connected to a third device, I had to re-do all of my pairings. SUPER ANNOYING.2. The earbuds do not power down when put in the case. Several times I would have the earbuds in the case and a phone call would come through. Answering the call, sent it to the earbuds in the case halfway across the house. SUPER ANNOYING.3. Placing the buds in the case was awkward. You do not simply pull the earbuds out of your ear and drop them into the case. Here is what you have to do: grasp the earbud (palm is facing you, thumb downward), take the earbud out, swivel your hand 180 degrees forward (palm is facing away from you, thumb is upward), then you can place the earbud in the case without any additional fumbling. SUPER ANNOYING.If you can live with those 3 problems, go ahead and buy them. As for me, the hunt for the best mid-price ear buds continues... Such a shame, these sounded absolutely amazing.Trying the Jabra Elite 7 now. So far, so good... but the sound is certainly inferior to the Liberty 3.

EDIT: Dropping these to a 2-star rating. The Bluetooth multi-point connection barely works. The earbuds do not automatically reconnect. When they do connect, sound sources don't switch to the buds automatically - I often have to close and re-start whatever media I am playing. The single/dual earbud thing is also a problem because every time you open the case the earbuds connect to...something - even if you can't hear anything (see my first comment above). Another issue is that the music player will start randomly sometimes when I take the earbuds out of the case and put them in my ear. These buds need a setting to turn off resume media. A lot of these things are bluetooth 101 and the cheapest of earbuds (including other Ankers!) do all of this fairly seamlessly. $200 is waaaaaay too much for these buds - they fail at the most basic of tasks. Finally bit the bullet and ended up getting a refund.ORIGINAL REVIEWI really love the Anker brand and own several pairs - my current favourite being the Liberty Air 2 Wireless. I also believe in the brand enough to have gifted various pairs to friends and family. This is why it pains me to say their latest flagship Liberty 3's were a little disappointing. Don't get me wrong - all of the things you expect from $200 headphones work as they should: transparency mode, ANC, decent noise-isolation, great sound and a good app experience with advanced features for sound and fit. All of this however means nothing if I can't use the headphones for more than a couple hours at a time. Comparing these to the Liberty 2's, the battery life is a fraction of what I used to get. These are definitely NOT all-day headphones. Doesn't seem to matter what mode (normal, ANC, transparency) battery life is still an issue. I hope a future firmware update can help improve this problem!TLDR: If battery life and basic bluetooth connectivity features are not important to you then the sound on these is great but NOT worth $200. Cannot recommend; look elsewhere.

reviewTitle: Think twice before you make the purchase
reviewDescription: First of all, it is a decent earbud. Sound quality, noise cancelling and battery are on standard within the price range. But! But! But! There are some cons you should be looking at before you make the purchase.1, I only used this earbuds average 2 hours a day for last 6 months, but some of the paint were off since the third month without dropping.2, I tried all the combinations of different sizes of buds and fins, but I just can't make the earbuds to stay in my ears even without any movement at all.3, Everytime I put the earbuds back to the pod for charging, I have to triple check that the earbuds are properly connecting to the pod so that they are charging.4, There were so many times that when I took out the earbuds from the pod, they couldn't connect to my phone.  I had to put them back to the pod, closed it and took them out several times to make them connect.It might be a decent earbud for someone else.  But if you are not in a hurry, I strongly recommend you to wait for S**y to go on sale rather than taking this one.

I purchased these bc I have a hard time keeping earpods in my ear and the custom wing/eartip combo seemed like a great option. Not so. The wings fall off pretty much everytime you touch the earpods, causing me to accidentally hang up on people frequently as I try to reposition or reattach. In addition, the right earpod is extremely low and I have found no way to adjust. For the cost, these are a huge disappointment!

reviewTitle: I wanted to like them so badly, but I don’t.
reviewDescription: After watching so many YouTube reviews saying this is the best earbuds ever, I bought a pair. Having many Soundcore products, from speakers to earbuds, I’ve always trusted their products. But these were disappointing. I am returning them.Pro : amazing, AMAZING sound quality once you do the hear ID customization. Not that great sound out of the box l, but once customized, they blew my mind. It sounds like you’re in a concert, literally. That’s pretty much the Only good thing about them.Cons : okay where do I start? First of all, they kept disconnecting, Bluetooth connection isn’t stable. Sometimes I go in a crowd and they keep losing connection every few minutes, as if they were interference sensitive. That’s the main reason why I am returning them. Other than that, putting them back in the case is very awkward, you have to turn and flip them in a certain way, you can’t put them back quickly. Sometimes it would stay connected to my phone even when in the case, and my phone would keep sending calls and music to the earbuds, even if they are put away. Touch buttons work half of the time, and these are pretty bulky in your ears.I really really wanted to like them, but I don’t. I own a pair of Liberty Air 2 Pro, and wanted something to replace them. I am very happy with my old anker ones, and yes these L3P sound way better, but for all the other negative aspects, I am returning them. Being a good Soundcore fan, it doesn’t ruin my trust completely in them, but it definitely puts a dent in my trust.

reviewTitle: Sound great if you can keep them in
reviewDescription: Never in a thousand years did I think I would be giving these a bad review because they don't stay in my ears.The wings are useless and just add mass to the already big and heavy bud. These things fall out all the time and are useless for work or hot days.Sound quality is shockingly competitiveANC is above averageBattery is greatConnectivity is perfectThe fit just DOES NOT work.It's just a heavy ball on a stick wedged into your ear like every other poorly designed wireless bud.It's crazy that Bose invented a shape that fits everyone's ears perfectly over a decade ago and were still doing the wings that haven't worked since the first Gbuds tried them.

reviewTitle: Worst experience using earphones, majority of positive reviews are from affiliate partners
reviewDescription: These earphones are terrible - no way around it. On paper, these would sound pretty good and honestly when I first got them I was surprised about the customization available and the out of the box sound quality. But that's where the pros end; these are the most frustrating earbuds I have had to use ever. First off, the fit. I've tried every single combination of wing and eartips (including using tips from different earbuds I had) and no one of them were secure in my ear. I find myself every few minutes having to push them back in or put them back after they've fallen out of my ear after minimal movement.  Second, these don't even connect most of the time! One of them constantly disconnects after they've been in the case for a while and I have to unpair them completely just to be able to connect and use them again. If I don't have the case then they becoming completely useless because you need the case to reconnect them again. The ANC is pretty terrible, virtually non-existent but honestly that's the least of my complaints. These are garbage buds and all the reviewers that say "oh my god they're just as good as Sony!!!!!" are spewing a bunch of b.s to you. Don't listen to these YouTubers, don't listen to these partners, understand the big names have earbuds with amazing reputations for a reason. Spend the extra $$ and just go with the Bose QuietComfort or Sony 1000mx4, they are MUCH more worth the extra money than these paper weights. These guys boast about their grammy award winning artists that worked on these and their tech, when in reality they can't make a decent pair of headphones that WORK LIKE THEY'RE SUPPOSED TO. Terrible, don't buy, I'm saving your wallet and peace of mind.

reviewTitle: So many issues from my 1 year of usage.....
reviewDescription: I bought these earbudss during 2022 prime day sale to replace my older Jabras. Other than the fact this can connect to 2 devices and have decent (not great) ANC (active noise cancellation), I keep experiencing a variety of issues:1. When I'm listening to music and a call comes in so I answer it, the audio from calls gets picked up by my phone instead of the earbuds (I've tested on iPhone and Samsung). This drove me crazy, and it happens no matter if you're calling via messenger, whatsapp, Google meet, Instagram, or just calling a number.2. The earbuds don't always connect properly to the charging prons in the case even if they both show lighted up. I've had multiple times where only 1 bud gets charged even though they're aligned.3. The case don't hold charge and always show only 1 LED as light up even after just removing from chord4. The touch sensitivity is insane if you have hair near your ears. I had to turn off all touch functions on the bud cause it keeps jumping around because it sensed my hair.5. Transparency mode is only good for transiting and listening to the PA announcements in subway, it's very bad if you want to have a conversation while having both earbuds in. The pass through mode external sound clarity is about same as regular mode on Apple's Airpods6. The "winged" removable of the silicone tip to fit into earl cannel easily falls off when when removing them from your ears.7. When I had the earbuds in while walking in light rain / drizzling weather, the touch sensitivity would also register the raindrops that does land on the bud8. I spent $140 + tax for these when they don't sound any better than a super cheap $30 wireless bt earbuds I bought from the brand Earfun as a temporary replacement for when I lost my old Jabras.These are all the issues I've learned to work around, but I also spent more on these Anker earbuds than my older Jabra 65T and the cheap Earfuns combined..... so.... 🙃The one pro: ability to connect to 2 devices at the same time and easily switch, that about it.

reviewTitle: Stopped working after getting wet, slipping out of the ears
reviewDescription: UPDATE: Their customer service is great, they reached out and sent me a new pair of headphones for free. Unfortunately, these ones had the same problem, both of them stopped working when wet. They were fine while I kept them dry, but after 5 days the right earbud stopped charging. So even the second product is unusable. Not sure if I want to try any of their other headphones ever again.I was very excited about these headphones as I had 2 headphones from this brand before. And I got disappointed.+++ The sound quality is great. The case is nice and small so you can keep it in your pocket comfortably.- - - There have been a few things I didn't like. The light of the case is strong in the dark but it doesn't light the inside of it properly so I couldn't fit the headphones back when going to sleep, had to turn the light on. They don't fit my ears properly, I was twisting them up and down trying to keep them in place, especially when they got wet. MOST IMPORTANT - the left headphone stopped working after it got wet. The sound was getting quieter and quieter on the left and disappeared completely. It was working again after it dried. But that's why I chose these headphones, I am planning to use them during any weather, any conditions.

I've had a very frustrating experience with this set of headphonesInitiallly I was excited by the functionality, the noise cancelling is great, they sound great, I never had it run out of batteryBut then I started noticing some quirksConnecting to multiple devices meant that one device would inevitably try to hijack them, whilst the other vied for superiority. It was a very annoying experience where sometimes I would pack my laptop up and somehow the earphones would connect to them. Which meant that my phone would not continue working with them.What's gotten me to write this review though is the fact that 3 months in, only one ear works consistentlyI basically have to setup the device from scratch to get the right ear to connect.Frankly speaking, this is unacceptable. I try and switch the order by which I pick the earphones from the case to no availAfter resetting, I see the right ear has full battery, I don't get itI regret purchasing this, it was very promising but having to deal with only one ear working is frustrating

The Anker brand is generally a good one. I had to scroll down past 5 other Anker purchases of mine (all of which I'm very happy with) in recent weeks to find these earbuds to write this review.These are phenomenal, though flawed (in quality) earbuds. They seem to loose synch with the hearing adjustment quite easily necessitating a resynch. Their dB range of adjustment is limited to 6 or so, so that's inadequate if you're trying to use them to assist a hearing disabled person. (Fair enough that's not their aim, no points deducted.)I've had these only two months and used them relatively lightly (Perhaps about 45 hours total, a mere one full recharge cycle). Already the left one is not reliably coming up and sooner or later it probably never will.I will update my review depending upon the response from Anker.Right now, I'd have to characterize them as a lovely product that is quite a gamble and not recommended unless you want to roll the dice.
I found batteri not holding more than  2 hoursMay be my unit have some issuesI have the liberty one last long all day last 3 years

This is the first set of Bluetooth headphones I've ever bought that glitches for a second. It just stops playing audio for a second and resumes. The music is not paused.Oddly enough the GF with a set of the cheaper newer model experiences the exact same issue.We contacted support and were told that it could be caused by Bluetooth interference. I've never encountered this issue with any BT headset I've ever had for the past 20 years, including my Liberty 2's and her old Anker set. Some use cases were the exact same (including location)!The sound on them is great though!

reviewTitle: Earbud clicks in noise canceling mode.
reviewDescription: I returned the first pair because of a clicking noise in the left earbud when the noise canceling is on. If you walk, eat, or sit in a moving vehicle the earbud makes a staticky clicking noise that matches the movement. It is completely distracting and makes these earbuds unusable in noise canceling mode…unless you like a repetitive click click click click click in one ear. I got another pair in hopes that it was just a fluke but the second pair does exactly the same thing but in the right earbud. I contacted customer support and confirmed I had all the firmware upgrades and did all the suggested resets, to no avail. I am returning this second set and moving on to another brand. I am super disappointed because of they sound and work great otherwise. If you pay $200 for something it should work the first time.

reviewTitle: Bad experiences after 3 months of use
reviewDescription: I watched many good reviews on this item which is the only reason why I bought this.After 3 months of use I have the following issues: - Voice calls: the mic quality is terrible. Often people cant even understand me.- Ear bud connectivity: major connectivity issues. Many times either the left or right ear bud doesn't turn on.- device connectivity: Many times the device has a hard time connecting to other devices such as mobile and computers making it very unusable.I would not recommend this product to anyone.

reviewTitle: Low vol out put at full vol, 2 earbuds having connection issues, hard to put into case
reviewDescription: Hard to believe all the YouTubers are says how good these earbuds are, noise cancellation etc. I will say don't buy this earbuds. I return them after trying it a few weeks, at full volume still it's lowbin output, noise cancellation give out a irritating noise, it's so hard to put it back in to case without looking each time. The biggest issue was connection issues btw two earbuds, one loose few sec and connect. It started happening again and againwhich made me return. Also  It's big on your ear but have large selection of buds to choose so it won't fall off but can't sleep with them has it stick outside... I'm happy with my new Samsung earbuds after returning this earbuds.. Please buy something else

If you’re buying AirPods for the first time and you’re planning to purchase online this reviews for you. first, I was hesitant whether to buy AirPods3rd or iPod Pro 2 and I ended up buying AirPod 3. Sound quality is ok but it was a little bit big for my ears and I didn’t feel hundred percent comfortable with it. later I had the chance to try AirPod Pro at the store and I was amazed by the sound quality And the noise cancellation feature. I immediately decided that I will go for AirPod Pro. If you are planning to spend more than 200 bucks on AirPods, go for AirPod Pro, it’s more convenient in the ears, the sound quality is way better and the noise cancellation feature is amazing. It totally worth + $70 investment.

reviewTitle: Hard to keep in your ears
reviewDescription: I find this product very hard to keep in my ears. It’s not that they’re not comfortable, but having them in my ears and using them for a bit of time every now and then one or the other just falls out for really no reason I don’t go walking with them. I don’t do anything but use them in my house and I don’t move around a lot with them but they just tend to fall out from time to time and that’s why I don’t want to use them anywhere outside the house cause I don’t wanna lose them.Other than that they seem to be fine.I’ve used wired Apple earbuds that come with my Apple phones over the years, and I’ve never had a problem, so I was surprised that I struggle with these.

reviewTitle: Great bass and battery, case is scratch-prone and it’s pricey.
reviewDescription: This product has great bass and overall the music quality is pretty good. It’s problem lies in the price and the case. The case is compact and holds lots of battery for the AirPods, but the plastic scratches instantly, after 5 days there were light and noticeable scratches under bright conditions. The price is absurd, the apple premium is a pretty penny, but you get really good connectivity to apple devices. They AirPods themselves fit great into my ear and connect seamlessly and having good audio quality, the bass is so much better then the first and second gens. If your going to buy AirPods, you might as well go for the Pros as they have noise cancellation and more features.

During first charge, RH was not charging, it was not seated properly.Feels a lot cheaper than the forst gen.Can't tap them to activate, you have to pinch them to feel a cheap click...Really dissapointed compared to the first gen...

Le nouveau design est trop gros pour se fixer correctement à l’oreille. Un simple bâillement les font tomber. Les générations précédentes n’ont pas ce problème et sont beaucoup plus stable. Mis à part ce problème important, les fonctionnalités et le son est très bien

reviewTitle: Ils sont plus gros que la première génération
reviewDescription: Le son est bon mais ils sont plus gros que la première génération. Donc ils tienne moins bien dans mes oreilles . J’en ai perdu un la deuxième journée. Je l’ai retrouvé avec le gps intégré mais une voiture avait piller dessus. J’aurais du les retourner après les avoir essayer

I suffer the same problem that others are citing.  They fall out of my ears.  I tried the tape trick that I found on line which was very uncomfortable for me.  I guess since I $200 in, I'll try the aftermarket cover that I see on line.The sound in and of itself is good.  Noise cancelling (if it's supposed to have it.  I don't think it  does) is nonexistent.  Battery life is quite good.  I am happier with the Sennheiser Momentums which I also own.  You may want to look at them as well
Pour écouter de la musique. Mais seul l’écouter droit fonctionne. Que faire?

reviewTitle: Too expensive for what they offer
reviewDescription: My earbuds stopped connecting to my iphone after 2 weeks. However, I’m leaving a review for the 2 weeks that it did work since apple is giving my money back.Now that I am headphoneless again, it got me thinking, “we’re these headphones really any good?” And in all honesty… not really. They are your typical wireless headphones with the slight advantage of connecting to your iPhone (if you have one) easily and an overall good sound experience. But that’s really the only nice things I can say about these.For the price, you would expect them to have more to them then other $100-250 earbuds but instead, this is how they stand up to others in the market that I’ve experienced:Sound: 8/10In ear fit: 5/10Price: 3/10Battery: 6/10 (-1,000,000 points for still using lightning charging and not having wireless charging included by default)I was expecting more :( I will not be buying these again with the return money.
These are pretty big and doest really block the surounding noises

reviewTitle: Decent but inferior to Gen 2 version
reviewDescription: I've had my Gen 2 for about 3 years now. And decided to get the Gen 3 version under the guise that it was a natural progression of the device. The good is that the sound output is pretty solid. It is also of solid build as you would expect from an Apple device.However if you are like me who's coming from an earlier version, then be wary of a few noticeable differences.Size: the gen 3 is noticeably shorter but rounder(fatter). As a result I found this version to be more uncomfortable and prone to slipping out. It doesn't quite have that secured(hook like) feeling, and I was always fearful of it falling out. Not sure why Apple changed the size of the airpods.Media control: I may be in the minority here but I used the tap feature on my Gen 2 frequently. And was surprised to see that this feature was changed to now button presses on the sides of the version 3. This a mind boggling change as the Gen 2 allows you to program the right and left buds. For example, double tapping the left may rewind and the right could fast forward. Of course you could change these to whatever suits you. This is a huge change and a feature I didn't know I needed. And just couldnt keep the Gen 3 due to this and the fit. I already felt anxious touching the sides of the Gen 3, so having to press the stems and risk it falling out was unneeded stress.So if you're a fan of Airpods Gen 2, just keeps these things in mind before getting the Gen 3. I ended up going back to getting a newer pair of Gen 2.Honestly if it ain't broken......

reviewTitle: Sérieux c’est pomal un scam cte marde là
reviewDescription: Ok sérieux, c’est d’la calisse de marde ces écouteurs làs. Mes anciens écouteurs Razer m’ont lachés pis y’en avaient plus faque j’ai commandé ces airpods là à la place, pis c’est fucking cheap comme écouteurs.1: le son chasse de gauche à droite sans aucun rapport2: le son est pas super fort faque si t’écoute une vidéo pis que y’a des chars qui passent à côté, ça se peut que tu entende mal ou rien pentoute si l’audio de la vidéo est pas assez fort.3: y tiennent pas bien dans les oreilles. Legit, si j’force du cou ou d’la mâchoire, les écouteurs viennent loussent pis vont tomber facilement après ça.4: pas bein bein de bass5:OSTI QUE LA BATTERIE TOUGH PAS. C’est tout le temps à recharger. Les écouteurs PIS le case.6: MAN, j’ai payé 200$ pour ça?!? C’est un scam for real.
Le son n'est pas bon ,j'ai du retourner l'article.

reviewTitle: Great sound but unacceptable fit in ears
reviewDescription: I purchased Apple AirPods (3) & Lightning Charging Case in March (200$). The sound is great however the fit in the ear is unacceptable. I purchased EarBuddy Hooks anti slip and ALXCD ear hooks accessories of little use. Due to the bad fit, I lost the right AirPod on a plane in May and was not able to find it. Not recommended!
Bluetooth isn't work, and refund take a whole month ...

reviewDescription: It doesn't have a real design because it doesn't fit all ears.  It makes you feel like he's not there, but he keeps slipping out of my ears and it scares me.  I have chosen to return.
It was used but wasn’t mentioned when ordered.Wouldn’t have ordered if knew ordering used

Both Airpods stopped connecting to my iPhone 13 within 3 months of ownership. First the right one would disconnect intermittently - within a week it stopped connecting all together. However, the left one continued working. A few weeks later, the left one stopped connecting too. I've tried doing the whole "forget device" and reset the Airpods shenanigans many times, which does nothing. Now I'm back to using a $20 pair of knock-off bluetooth earbuds which are working great. The Airpods are still under warranty so I suppose I have to find the time to make an hour's journey to the closest Apple store to get a replacement before the warranty expires.
Sound quality is noticeably improved over gen2. The quality and performance you would expect from Apple, along with the price.

I was worried that they wouldn’t fit in my ear but they did and they absolutely work perfect with my iPhone. Sound quality is great. I can answer the phone make a phone call to someone in my directories and even text someone from my contact list. 🤙
Good quality and excellent sound quality.
Bought these for my daughter she likes that they are not as long as the Gen 2 and fit better in her ears.
Bought these for my daughter,she’s really impressed with the sound quality
I thought these would be a fake but they are real. Lol the sound is good. I’ve had these for a few months now. I bought it when it was on sale. So definitely a good buy.

Airpods are of good sound quality there is no cracking sound and are tap able.

If I could give this zero stars I would. Bought these for our daughter as an x-mass gift. 4 months later they stop working. Apple replaced only the ear buds and not the case. Here we are just a little past a year from the original purchase date, only to have the same issue and no remaining warranty. Don’t buy this product. Spend your money on JBL. Better sound quality and performance, at a fraction of the price.

reviewTitle: poor sound quality on right side
reviewDescription: when i bought them i hardly used them, now i am using more often i find the sound great on left side but right side you can hardly hear anything i was thinking it was just the song but tried multiple songs and there is very minimal sound and i am very dissappointed as i spent over 200 bucks for these

reviewDescription: Design is Awful, if you have a small ears, the airpods won’t fit. Returning it and order The 2nd gen which fits perfectly

I should have listened.It appears the only way to unpair them is to contact the previous owner. If there is another way, please let me know, otherwise I will return them.

I orderd airpods on 10th March. It worked fine for two months, then the sound of right side airpod got low and now it has stopped working. I reported the issue to customer service agent and they agreed to refund me. But what i came to know , I'm getting only $126.99 back. But i could return it within three months for full refund, if it gets damaged.

reviewTitle: Great Water Resistance and Vey Durable
reviewDescription: I bought these because the were the mid tear option between the pros and 2nd gen. I really liked them but decided to return them because I really wanted noise cancelling. But they are very good for what they are. The water resistance is very good, dropped them in the sink with the tap on and nothing happened to them. The only down side is when you do things like running they tend to fall out, this was just my experience so it may not be like that for you. Definitely recommend.
Enjoying the music with this one. Really like this product. But one this is I feel like it doesn’t stick firmly to my ear.
Personnellement

I love these. the sound is really good and i like the spatial audio feature (even if it kind of feels like my music is playing out loud and everyone can hear it sometimes).the only thing is it took some time to get used to the feel of them in my ears after i was used to the smaller size of the older gen airpods and the wired earpods.
