These earphones deliver excellent sound quality and a secure fit that doesn't let them fall out. The only downside is that the charging case is damaged; I need to press it to keep it closed. Due to time constraints, I couldn't send it back, which is why I'm giving it a 4-star rating.

reviewTitle: You get what you pay for
reviewDescription: Durable

These sound really great. I used the equalizer in the Spotify app and customized the sound to my liking through the AirPods. The only down side … I was using Galaxy Buds prior and I find the AirPods can fall out much easier.

Battery life was good, I have not experienced any runout. Sound quality is good, not as good as my JBL but better than average. Very comfortable. Not sure if this buds can only pair with a single device. But switching it between my phone and my watch was close to impossible, had to reset the buds each time which was very frustrating. The most disappointed part was the voice quality. Wasn't expect that to be an issue since this buds was advertised for calls. Used it once for a MS Teams meeting, ppl couldn't hear me at all. Then tested it on my phone voice recording, same result, paired it with my laptop, did a test meeting call, same result. I can barely hear anything through it's mic. searched on Google, seems like there are tons of users complaining about the same issue. So if you are planning to buy this for your work or phone calls, don't buy it!
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewDescription: I had a Jabra elite 4 active  for a year. The right earbud works, but it will run out of battery a few hours earlier than the left one, and often the right one won’t turn on and I have to do a reset. Because of this, I decided to buy a newer one thinking it was because it is an older model. I bought the elite 7 active. It came and the right earbud was not working. The reset and things I google to fix it didn’t work. I requested a return and ordered an elite 7 pro because it was the only one available. The exact same thing happened. Both the elite 7 pro and active came with a non-working right earbud. This is obviously a consistent quality issue over their entire line. I won’t be buying jabra anymore, even though they fit my ears very well.
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewTitle: 2 broken pairs out of the box
reviewDescription: buy one of the older models like the 75t or just go for Sennheiser. bought a pair the right ear bud wouldnt charge did all the troubleshooting but because it wouldnt charge the ear buds just kept saying place in case to finish reset which i did but it wouldnt charge so it would reset got a replacement it took 3 times as long to arrive as just buying a new pair and the excat same issue on the second pair. went through jabra support which was fairly convient to get another replacement but after a week all i have is a ticket number with no informantion on when a replacement may be provided
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewDescription: Transitioning between connected Bluetooth devices is poor and annoying, earbuds are plastic and not especially durable, and noise cancelling quality is alright but automatically engages and disengages sometimes at random. For what I paid for them, these headphones were not worth it in my opinion and the quality of the offering is comparable to a brand like Anker which you could get for about 1/3 the price.If you are going to buy this item, know that the price variation on this item is pretty high, so probably wait and buy it when it's less expensive, and get additional coverage. All things considered, I would go out of my way to not buy anything from this company in the future.
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewDescription: I generally do not write reviews however these are so bad that I want people to know before they buy these. I bought this 7 pro model for my office work thought since they are professional version will be good for calls. However they are the worst, while on office call on Teams or Webex the microphone performs terrible the other people on call can never hear me. I always have to disconnect these earbuds and just use regular laptop microphone and speakers in between the calls. I reached out to Jabra support and their answer was that these earbuds are only compatible for phone calls and not for online meetings. I mean if that is the case why don't they mention it in the item description somewhere. Whereas they promote these earbuds as best for professionals. In todays world people use Teams and Webex for professional calls more than cell phone. I have been using a standard $80 earbuds before this and they sound excellent on Teams calls compared to Jabra. My question is low cost earbuds can do so well it is a shame that a company like Jabra is struggling with this.On top of everything their customer support is terrible, hard to reach tech support over the phone, only option you have is to leave a message.Ill say you are better of buying any other pair compared to Jabra.
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewTitle: Piece of junk of a bad batch?
reviewDescription: One earbud never power on (no light, no sound) from the beginning. After trying everything I've found on Jabra website and on the internet, I asked for a replacement and the other pair was exactly doing the same thing. The left earbud never had power, even after charging, resetting, repairing, etc. I wonder if it's a bad batch or something because a friend of mine just bought a pair and he has the exact same problem, even though they are well reviewed.

reviewDescription: Please don't buy this product.It does not  connect.Did all troubleshooting without success.Returning.Amazon please take this off your website

reviewDescription: Read quite a few reviews some you believe and some you question, unfortunately many of the key points people pointed out as to why they were not happy or returned are true. reviewTitle: Decent but does not sync well to the phone
reviewDescription: The product does what is advertise. The sound is clear, the ear buds are light, microphone is okay but Im still on the fence about it and the case is quite sturdy. I like that it has magnets to keep the ear buds in place. But I have been having problems syncing the ear buds to my phone and just watching videos/playing games.I thought it was my phone at first but after using these ear buds for a while, it was more the app/earbud itself. This is my second pair of Jabra's since I used to own the elite 65t and those were excellent, clear microphone, decent sound, and quite durable but quite heavy on the ears.I play rhythm games ever so often but the sync is off by about 2-3 seconds. I didnt notice until I closely watch a video and the mouth movement. Which is weird since the elite 65t never had that problem or the lag was minimal.Overall I think it's a decent pair of earbuds.Microphone...decentSound...excellentBattery life...decent but the case drains quicklyOnly problem is the syncing to phone, videos and phone games and for the price well... It would be better if you waited for a sale.

reviewDescription: These earbuds are great. reviewDescription: After years of hearing about Jabra earbuds, I was excited to hear the hype for myself.The Elite 7 Pros' left me rather disappointed. The case itself is bulky and looks dated. The earbuds themselves, while relatively compact — unfortunately for me, they felt very uncomfortable and terrible after 20 minutes of normal usage. There are also no air-vents to help alleviate the pressure sensation, which I found surprising for ANC earbuds.The sound profile is average at best, and certainly nothing to rave about (again for the brand name and the MRSP asking amount of such premium earbuds). The bass is while decent, highs / trebles often sounded harsh and even over-processed at times. ANC technically works but only to a minimum degree, therefore making it subpar in quality. I was rather surprised as the Elite 7 Pros' are Jabra's most recent flagship earbuds. The transparency / "hear through" mode doesn't work well and isn't really noticeable when on or off. Phone call quality sounded terrible and was the ultimate deal breaker for me...as if you're speaking to someone underwater (it has a horrible odd distortion / high-pitch artificial sound). The app works as advertised, but is also buggy and has it's own set of issues (random odd connectivity dropouts).Everything with these flagship earbuds left me wanting so much more (especially at full MRSP). I was really underwhelmed and disappointed, ending up returning these earbuds the very next day (even though I got these on sale with $100 off).Honestly, I would look elsewhere and can not recommend getting the Jabra Elite 7 Pros' at full asking price. There are definitely better, more modern earbud options these days — at the same price or even at the sub $200 price range. The Jabra Elite 7 Pros' regrettably feel stuck in the past, as if they had come out in late 2019 — which is rather uninspiring and unfortunate.
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewTitle: Neutral Sound, Great Transparency Mode, Solid App ... Lousy Call Quality
reviewDescription: Likes* After trying a half a dozen earbuds and headphones to test their transparency mode, there was only one non-Apple set that approached the Airpod Pro 2 earbuds they were replacing in quality, and that was the Jabra Elite 7 Pros. I could have a normal conversation with them in. Most products sound like you're talking in a bathtub, and some were truly atrocious (Surface 2 Headphones ... wow, bad).* Unlike many earbuds, the sound profile is neutral, so you don't get the boomy bass and rolled off treble that's typical of most earbuds. If you're a fan of jazz, classical, acoustic music, or any other genre that can benefit from neutrality, you owe it to yourself to try these. The resolution is quite good, too, as is the sound staging.* The app is truly a one stop shop to administer the earbuds, and the ability to tailor their response to your actual hearing (yes, that's an option) may be a bit frightening if you're like me and discover you have significant hearing loss in one ear, it can only help get you a more balanced response from the earbuds.Dislikes* When assigning options to the button on each earbud, volume is not one of the options. This leaves you to use a digital assistant to raise or lower the volume, or the rocker on your phone. With my old Airpod Pro 2 earbuds, I could do the volume right from the earbuds themselves.* Update: I have had multiple callers tell me they can barely hear me on the other end, using terms like 'you sound like you're underwater' or 'you sound like you're talking through a mask'. The minute I switch to speaker, they can hear me fine. This is an issue noted by MANY owners of this set of earbuds, as well as other previous models (75t). Detective work on the Internet shows that this problem has been at least a couple of years since discovery, with no fix, and with prior models showing the same issues, it's clear there's no fix coming. I still LOVE the sound of these earbuds, and continue to use them for music consumption, but the minute I find another set of earbuds that approach this neutrality and still let me make a decent phone call, these are going into the garbage. The entire point of earbuds like this is that you have a full headset. I can't be switching to speaker phone all the time.

reviewTitle: Terrible call quality. DO NOT BUY
reviewDescription: I purchased these for use on my PC and android phone. I downloaded the app, customized my preferences, installed the latest firmware. Look and feel is good, performance is not.On my phone - Audio quality is very good when listening to music, but there is a significant delay when watching any sort of accompanying video. ANC is only ok, hearthrough is very bad (it just amplifies even the lightest background noise - a quiet fan whirring becomes really loud).On my PC - Audio quality has mild background static regardless of what I'm doing. Microphone quality is similarly bad. I also hear a static pop anytime I change from audio only to something that accesses the microphone.Overall, really disappointed in my decision to try out this Jabra product and I'll be returning them immediately to try out another brand. I tried any number of troubleshooting options and nothing helped. If call quality matters to you at all, do not buy these. reviewDescription: I got these earbuds so I could stop fiddling with wires when listening through my phone and PCs, and hoped to use the same device for calls and media.I found the audio quality for music to be very good when listening on my phone.  It wasn't as good when trying to use it for video conferencing through a PC - the audio was not very crisp, and too quiet.Audio latency also seems to be a problem with these earbuds, especially when connected to a PC.  It is very noticeable and off-putting when watching videos or participating in video calls.Finally, a user who is sensitive to having their ears plugged probably won't be able to get the best active noise cancellation experience with these earbuds.  I couldn't tolerate a "proper" seal, as then I could hear my heartbeat and creaking joints, so I had to use the smallest provided eargels which allow outside noise to bleed through.In the end, at nearly $200 CAD after tax and a Prime Day discount, I felt I was not getting enough value from these earbuds, and will be returning.

reviewTitle: Excellent overall and best call quality
reviewDescription: Upgraded from the 85t after trying multiple competition products - Sony, Beats and Nothing which had distinct downsides that made them no go.Call quality is exceptional and the noise reduction is the best of anything I've tested. I have gotten complaints with every pair other than these and have been asked multiple times to recommend. Loud noises are barely heard by the other side while I can still hear their voice clearly over the sound of wind and cars. Noise reduction is  miles ahead the competition, likely due to the bone conduction tech.Fit is great and more comfortable than bigger and looser fitting 85t. These stay on much better and have never fallen off. I've worn them for hours and do not notice them.Transparency is good to the point I don't take them off anymore to hear ambient noise. Perhaps Apple is better but I don't think the difference is noticeable overall.ANC is good. Maybe Sony is 15% better but are 50% less comfortable and have 2ay worse noise reduction during calls. I don't think this trade-off is worth it. ANC blocks subway noise completely. I don't think people should be expecting a tomb of silence with earbuds.Battery life is great and no complaints. Case and buds charge fast and also wirelessly. Case is tiny. It does spill the buds of you drop the case but I have yet to find one that doesn't.Audio is great but was maybe 5% better on the 85t. Hard to notice unless you look for it.Connectivity is excellent. Have not had a single issue with interference, drops or slowness in connection and I use these every day on a crowded train where literally 100s of people are on wireless buds. People calling out connection issues must have a bad pair and should return.
variant: Colour Name: Titanium BlackStyle: Elite 7 Pro

reviewTitle: Better and cheaper than AirPods Pros
reviewDescription: These sound incredible, better than my AirPods Pros and the battery life is almost double. They are more comfortable laying down with the side of your head on a pillow than my AirPods Pros. the case is a bit flimsy, hard to open with one hand and charging port should be on the back of the case not the front of the case. I paid CAD$160 for these which is literally half the price of airpod pros. I am happy with my purchase. Give your money to this modest danish company instead of greedy American companies!Ps download the jabra app and update the firmware, it adds and fine tunes many features of these earbuds.edit: 2 months in I'm blown away by the battery life of these earbuds. I'd be surprised if anything can touch these in that regard. I'm also a big fan of the button on each earbud as opposed to my airpods touch/squeeze controls. case is definitely the weakest link but its passible with how good the buds are. noticeable audio lag compared to my airpod pros paired with my iphone (thats due to apples M1 chip in airpods its designed for low latency on iphone). both have around the same audio lag on PC

reviewTitle: These are really great. Decent app, and verbal action ques
reviewDescription: I first ordered the 7 Active but returned it because the right cup had an annoying shifting high pitch whine, and got this one (which had no whine at all).Why would I bother doing that rather than picking a different company? I actually liked a lot about it and if not for the whine Id have kept it.This has ok battery life (wish the case had a few more charges), good audio, decent features.I really like for instance that every action made results in a voice giving you a voice telling you what is going on. "Battery Low", "2 Devices connected" etc. No incomprehensible tones  and jingles you are expected to remember.I also like that you can to some degree change what the buttons do. I wish the customization was more free form, but its barely acceptable there.Comfort wise they didn't feel like they were going to fall out for me, and something important to me is their shape means I can lie down sideways in bed with them on, which is great. If they didn't have auto switch off that would be a problem. That being said I'm not sure it works perfectly 100 percent of the time as sometimes I wake up and one side is still on while the other went to sleep. I would add more hut I haven't had that much time with them. Decent app though.I ended up returning the 7 pros as well, but that's because mine came with the accessories inexplicably missing. I still recommend them though and will just get the same ones again.

reviewTitle: Works really well with iOS and MacOS
reviewDescription: My Jabra MOVE 2.5 on-ear phones have worked really well over many years. At one point I tried an 'upgrade' to Jabra ear buds. It turned out that they didn't work well with my Mac Mini M1 and older iPhone. So they went back and I bought new ear pads for the MOVE 2.5s and splashed for AirPod Pros.I had forgotten all about that fail when I ordered these Jabra 7 Pros. On their arrival I found (again) that the Jabra app is only available for iOS, so I started the return process again. Fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, silly me. Right?But I did give them a try, expecting the worst ... and finding something really good. The app controls for equalizer and ANC, sound modes, etc. actually work for both the bluetooth connections to my iPhone 12 Pro and Mac Mini M1. When you hear "Two devices connected" everything works together.The case is a bit awkward to open without grips or indentations, and the USB-C connector would be better placed on the back, but wireless charging resolves this. ANC is never perfect but these are very good. They're more comfortable than my AirPod Pro 2s, feel lighter in the ear and have a longer battery life. Combined with the sound quality it meant that I had to tear up the RMA. I'm keeping these.

reviewDescription: As an audiophile, I eagerly anticipated trying a Sony sound product, and the WF-1000XM5, which I purchased during a Black Friday sale, seemed like the perfect choice. Given the product's higher price point, my expectations for premium quality were high. Here's my detailed assessment after a week's usage:Pros:Sound Quality: The audio performance of the WF-1000XM5 is nothing short of outstanding. The sound is exceptionally clear and crisp, with perfectly balanced bass. The customization options available exceed any of my previous experiences, including those with AirPods Pro.Battery Life: The battery longevity is impressive, easily supporting extended listening sessions without frequent recharging.Cons:Ergonomics: The design is where the WF-1000XM5 falls short. The earbuds are round and constructed from a glossy, slippery plastic, making them difficult to handle both in and out of the case. This design flaw has led to several instances of dropping them, despite my careful handling.App Interface: While the accompanying app is functional, it's somewhat cumbersome to navigate. The explanations for advanced features are not as clear as they could be, necessitating a steeper learning curve for users.Conclusion:The Sony WF-1000XM5 earbuds are a sonic delight, sure to satisfy any audiophile's cravings for high-quality audio. However, the ergonomic design is a significant drawback, posing a risk to the durability of this substantial investment. Users should be extra cautious to avoid literally see your investment going down the drain. Overall though, they offer an exceptional audio experience but require careful handling.

Passive noise canceling of the foam is excellent, even better than a earplug.... except it's uncomfortable to me.  After switching to a silicone alternative (AZLA SednaEarfit MAX standard) there's barely any passive noise canceling left.  Also surprisingly the ANC is very weak, it's heavily reliant on passive noise canceling to block out noise.  There's barely any silicone eartips with mesh on the market.  Noise canceling is next to nothing if you don't use foam.The battery is excellent, 9 hours playtime if I don't use any of the battery hungry settings.  Those are ANC, dsee extreme, and prioritize quality.  The playback hours I'm getting is about 75% of their claimed hours.  Which is still a lot.

reviewTitle: Almost Perfect -Had to buy alt eartips
reviewDescription: Sound, custom eq, noise cancellation & battery r all amazing and as an apple user, I prefer them over the airpod pros in all categories except for comfort. The foam tips are pretty bad, particularly in my right ear and after 2hrs it feels like a fiery mess. Not so sure why they don't give alt silicone tips but sony j silly like that I guess. After some searching around I found that the "AZLA SednaEarfit MAX for TWS" silicone tips are quite literally the best upgrade possible. They feel as comfortable as the airpods and there's no noticeable loss in sound quality but a slight loss in ambient noise cancellation (cus the foam ones r pretty much like earplugs). I use em everywhere I go now and really enjoy them for long study sessions- Occasionally one of the buds will glitch out and get stuck in the transparency mode but that fixes when putting them back in the case and pulling them out again.

Ear plugs are second rate. Dont fit or hold properly. The noise cancellation is optimal with a pair of foam plugs that fit too loosely in the ear canal.. Never a perfect fit.  Noise cancellation is great. Sound is great with modifiable equalizer settings.. Unfortunately their is a lack of options for the left and right ear controls.The bluetooth connections for 2 devices are seamless once setup. Go from phone to TV no problem,no adjustments,no pain. Would give 5 stars but  for the fit

The audio is pretty good, NC is great, bass is good as well for buds, however the buds themselves are very ‘slippery’ when trying to remove them from the case and your ears, I am very afraid of them slipping out of my fingers every single time. The app isn’t bad either, a little confusing and over engendered, but not bad as it has lots of options. 3rd party BT buds just don’t work as well as Apples (for obvious reasons).

Certainly better than my Jabra 65T, and pleased with my purchase, especially with the 20% price reduction. Full price would have been too much to pay for it. Sound is great but not as good as my Sony headphones. Only “gripe” is the volume on my iPhone has to be turned up higher than usual.😕
They're Awesome, but not staying in my ears. APP is saying the correct fit is Large Foam. Going to try others.

Here we have the Sony WF-1000XM5 up for review. They are world class leading when it comes to Active Noise Cancellation and that is apparent as soon as you put these on. Starting with the material that is used to insert in your ear lobe. It’s not a rubber like other models I’ve used but this is more of a foam material which helps these buds from falling out of my ears compared to many other buds I’ve tried. They also really help to create a strong seal which is crucial for any good ANC headphone. The sound quality of these are amazing and can even be further improved to your liking by installing the app and using the built in EQ. It’s not just a simple EQ that allows you to control treble or bass. So you start by playing some music and it presents you with different options to choose from, based on the sound that sounds best to you after a few selections voila you have your personalized custom EQ setting created! You can create multiple personalized EQ’s for all different genre types. This was a setting that really impressed me. Sound quality is top notch after installing the app and setting up the EQ. I tried the 360 Reality Audio and it is really impressive. Takes these buds to the next level of immersion. The app itself is really easy to use and has all the settings that you’d expect to get with a quality pair of wireless headphones. You can see the battery percent of each bud as well as the charging case battery. Battery life on these last hours and the case should provide an additional 3 charges so you don’t ever have to worry about your battery dying with these. They charge up super fast too. Honestly no complaints here. Don’t worry we’ll get to what I didn’t appreciate as much soon and where I think these could be improved.Cons/room for improvements:- These buds are hard to take out of their charging case because of their smooth plastic design. I wish they were easier to handle and pull out of their case.- the touch functionality is a hit or miss. For me it’s mostly a miss. If you happen to touch your headphones to readjust them in your ears you may turn ANC on or off or enable Passthrough mode by accident. Sometimes I pause my music by mistake. Luckily you can turn off the touch settings in the app and just use your phone to change song or raise or lower the volume if needed.- the pass through isn’t great either compared to something like the AirPods. With these it feels like the surrounding sounds are being played in your ear like a speaker making it sound less natural.- the price of these are definitely on the higher end of the spectrum.Overall:Overall I would rate these a 4/5 based on my experience using them and taking everything into consideration. If they were maybe $100 cheaper I would easily recommend these but due to the high asking price (currently $429.99 CAD) these are probably not the best value you can find in 2023. They are great quality headphones don’t get me wrong but are definitely not perfect.

reviewTitle: Qualité sonore impressionnante application très complète recharge sans fil rapide 24H d'autonomie
reviewDescription: Vient avec 4 formats d'embouts d'oreillettes, très petits, petits, larges et les moyens sont déjà installés sur les écouteurs.Le câble USB-A/USB-C est très court, seulement 20 cm, la prise murale n'est pas incluse. Heureusement, le boîtier est compatible avec la recharge sans fil, se recharge très rapidement, soit en environ 1h15 avec les écouteurs et permet de les recharger jusqu'à 2 fois pour une autonomie allant jusqu'à 24 heures d'utilisation au total. La lumière est rouge pendant la recharge ou que le niveau est bas, s'éteint lorsque c'est terminé et devient verte en ouvrant le couvercle pour nous aviser qu'il est prêt à charger les écouteurs.Il n'y a pas beaucoup d'instructions incluses, mais l'application multilingue est très complète pour nous guider, afficher l'état des batteries en plus de permettre plusieurs ajustements.Une fois l'option "360 Reality Audio" optimisée et le son ajusté à notre goût avec l'égaliseur, la qualité sonore est vraiment impressionnante pour des intra-auriculaires, très claire et les basses sont puissantes.Il y a une bonne période d'adaptation au début, le temps de trouver la bonne façon de les porter pour qu'ils restent bien en place et que ce soit confortable.Il y a énormément de contrôles possibles, en touchant le gauche, ainsi que le droit ou bien par commandes vocales et même avec certains mouvements de la tête.Avec mon iPhone 11, la portée du signal Bluetooth est d'environ 10 mètres.La suppression du bruit est très efficace en écoutant de la musique, mais beaucoup moins avec la radio parlée ou les balados.Il y a même des avertissements sonores dans la langue de notre choix, pour nous aviser par exemple que le niveau des batteries est bas.Dès qu'on les enlève de nos oreilles, ça arrête ce qu'on était en train d'écouter.En conclusion, excellent produit haut de gamme aux possibilités surprenantes.

reviewTitle: Fit is ok, fantastic sound quality
reviewDescription: I've been using the Sony WF-1000 XM5 earbuds for the last two weeks to work with at my home office and here are my thoughts:For one, comfort, is so so. I happen  to  have the Bose high end earbuds, which although are a bit larger, fit far more comfortably. I do have a peculiar ear canal shape on one ear, so that does make it trickier for me to be comfortable and for the buds to stay onIf I just stay at my desk and work, browse, look around, the buds stay on no problem. I would not walk around much in these, even  less do any form of activity.Before I go into sound quality, the noise cancelation, which it has three levels of, is pretty good, but is not stellar.  I could still hear the ceiling fan this weekend (I was at a cottage that had one) when I was on full noise cancellation. The feedthrough, or ambient noise setting, where you can hear your surroundings quite well, is actually pretty cool. You can hear what's going on everywhere; I could hear the crickets outside with the windows closed.  I find the noise cancellation could have been better. Most of the cancellation is done by the buds. They fit so tightly, that it blocks a lot of the sound.Now for the quality: My favorite part was setting up the custom equalizer through the app. Very cool. It will have you go through a series of choices to pinpoint what your favorite eq settings are.Once that is done, wow, the sound is fantastic. Crystal clear, excellent sound with pretty darn good low frequencies.It supports the usual SBS and AAC codecs as well as LDAC, which sounds fantastic when using it  (my Sure Aonics headsets  spoiled me with the LDAC codec). No aptX, which is a shame, if you like to watch tv and have a transmitter for that (low latency).They come in a really nice and small case. Very easy to carry around.All in all, they sound fantastic. At what they are selling now, discounted, three forty eight, is much better than full price, which I dont think they deserve full list price.
Sound quality is okay, but doesn't reflect the high price.

reviewTitle: Good Features but has poor design. Not worth the price!
reviewDescription: Firstly I am fan of wf1000xm4 ear buds and it was the best in the market at the time I purchased it. Recent firmware upgrade from sony has screwed the xm4 device performance leading to quick battery drain issues. After raising a case with Sony they offered to provide full refund after I returned back the device. So I had purchased wf1000xm5 ear buds. I really wish sony tests the firmware thoroughly before rolling it out to the users.wf1000xm5 has all the best features in the market. But it has been rolled out with poor design. The polished sides on the ear buds is very slippery and it makes it difficult to pick it out from the case as well as placing in the ears. it would have been good with matte finish itself if it was like xm4. Even though the features are outstanding but this slippery polished sides on the earbuds is a big flaw for everyday use. As the customer have to experience this through the products lifetime. Exterior design is poor than low cost alternatives in the market.Definitely worth considering if this exterior flaws doesnt matter much for anyone.

reviewTitle: WF1000XM5, run away don't look back
reviewDescription: Overpriced, poor fitting, sloppy design no metal hunge on the case, poor selection of materials the ear buds are too slippery the tooling on the case isn't high quality the earbuds slip out of charge position while in the case all the time they also slip out of your ears and the earbud tips don't clean well alcohol will destroy them, they suffer from Bluetooth interference, the charge the case holds could be better.These are so bad I will never buy Sony anything ever again.

reviewTitle: Noise Cancelling issues not as advertised, - DO NOT BUY
reviewDescription: I'm a big fan of Sony, and have the Sony WF1000XM4 that work flawlessly. ( I've been a fan since the Sony Walkman in 1982)I purchased the WF-1000XM5 and one of the best features, the noise cancelling, doesn't work. I had Sony issue a replacement that also didn't work, and thinking it could be an operator error, spend 30 minutes making sure it wasn't my configuration.After issues on my 2nd pair, I had fallen outside of the Amazon return window, and Sony warranty support gave me 2 options;1) return the unit and they will replace it in 10-14 days, which is not an option, as I know that the 3rd unit will have the same issue, as the XM5 noise cancelling is sub-par at best.2) Return the unit and "maybe" they will issue me, as a favour, a refund in 4-6 weeks.DO NOT buy this item, and consider anything but.

Bare bones headphones. Didn't come with a charge cord or additional ear pieces. The one fit that was available was uncomfortable and the material on the ear piece started to flake off after only a few days of use. In addition to that the battery wouldn't hold a charge anywhere close to what was advertised. I'd get low battery warnings after 1 hr of use when they were in the case charging all night. Very disappointing.

I found that the esrbuds where not very good st noise canceling at all compared to the don't m3 over the esr series. Infact it was harder to set up and when work only was 10 percent of what the over the ears was capable of. I would suggest notvspending money on the Sony ear buds. I was greatly disappointed. In the performance.
If you have an Apple phone do not waste time to buy them they come off easily from your ears , they do not read messages and the price is not worth it. I bought them they did not connect to my IPhone
I bought it for almost $500 the headphones were making bad noises the chat basicly send me to go ** myself & close the coversation after less than a minute

After trying to use these for work phone calls for a couple of weeks, I got sick of people complaining about terrible call quality. Tired calling Amazon to return them, but they wouldn’t take them back! I’m now stuck with these overpriced crap headphones!

reviewTitle: Horrible battery issues unaddressed by Sony
reviewDescription: Don’t get these. Since the XM4s, battery has uneven drain issues. Sony completely refuses to fix this, they are well aware. Lasted me 3 days before problems started. Absolute garbage.

reviewTitle: Sound quality great, battery good, all else not so good
reviewDescription: Sound quality is indeed great, seem good for calls, battery is good but i noticed some weird stuff happening, i will update on that later. Whats annoying is when you take the earbuds out of the box for longer without connecting them or the box is out of battery and  you can't turn them on even though they have battery, so i ha e to put them back in the box to wake them, and if the box is out of battery you have a problem even though they have battery. Thats stupid. The app also acts up with annoying notifications and the touch controls are not as configurable as they should. Some feature are annoyingly useless.Now the worst. The fit is very bad. Although they are very light the fit is based on the ear canal so it's not trustworthy and one tends to stay in a position and the other in another. As mush as i try to push them in, with the right size foams, i can ear them slipping out. I can't feel them secure in place although they never actually came off by them selfs completely, nonetheless its annoying. Also and something that kinda seems on purpose for you to loose one of them and have to buh it again is that the earplugs are very slippery. I mean why would you make something so smal and valuable so polished in a way they can easily slip out of your hands when grabbing them... Seems so obvious that i doubt that wasn't on purpose.For context i previously had the Sennheiser true wireles first edition, the sound quality was pretty much the same as these but the battery was bad and they had a defect that caused the battery to run out in 2 days or less, and they were very bad fo calls. But they had excellent fit and grip. Basically you just put it in your ear and twist it and it locks in place, the more you twisted it the more secure it got, was perfect aside from a litle disconfort that you got used to. I never ever had to ajust them on contraire of these sonys.All in all not worth the money at least untill sony makes a solution for the fit. I only didn't return them because i didn't like the ones from bose and i wouldn't buy the new Sennheiser true witeless because i think they should have sent replacements for a product that was defective.The box from these sonys also feels cheap.I'm a big fan of Sony for a long time but i think they didn't properly tested this ones and the reviews i read were rushed too.

I used to only use headsets and I loved my WH-1000XM4. Now the WF-1000XM5 is my first wireless earbuds. The sound quality of WF-1000XM5 is at least on par with WH-1000XM4, if not better. Noise cancelling in outdoor environment with a lot of traffic is not as good as WH-1000XM4, but this might be because of how the WH-1000XM4 cups the ears.Now the real issue with WF-1000XM5 is the bluetooth. I have experienced different issues very frequently and I'm listing those that I remember below:* It happened twice that when connected to both my Android phone and macbook, the macbook steals the connection and I could not disconnect it with the Headphones app my phone. Even putting the buds back in the charging case did not fix it. I had to open my macbook and disconnect it from there.* Occasionally when I play media on my macbook, I could hear stuttered sound for a second and then no sound anymore. It recovered when I put them back in the case and took them out.* The app on my Android phone sometimes just refuse to connect to the earbuds.* The funniest thing I have experienced once is for some reason the two earbuds connected to different devices.Simply put, when it works, it works really well, but you have to be mentally prepared when it refuses to work.

reviewTitle: Excellent sound if you can get the fit right
reviewDescription: Lovely sound. Joni Mitchell's voice on her album "Mingus" was silky smooth, marginally better than Apple Airpods or Bose earbuds, both version 1. Almost as good as my Bose QC ANC headphones. Bass balanced and very tight. Beautiful sound of the tabla on Shakti's albums. Nice design; easy to keep in pocket. Here are the downsides:1. Fit: I got a reasonable fit with buds but the fit was not secure. If I turned my head or used my jaw, they would dislodge enough to affect the fidelity. Have to be motionless to listen!2. Comfort: I found my ears became a little after 2-3 hours of listening. The earbud material is quite firm.3. Controls: Sony built in several controls into the body. The problem is that they also interfere with attempts to adjust the buds because of problem #1. When I tried to resecure the buds due to #1, I would end up inadvertently changing a track. Can probably turn off some of these features but it would be good if there was a part of the bud that one could touch without affecting controls.

I switched to these from my galaxy buds 2 pro. in comparison, these ones sound quite a bit better (after some eq adjustments), have better noise cancelling (but not as good as bose), better battery life, and true multi pairing. The mic sounds better as well.Unfortunately I had to return them but may re-buy (next time they are on sale) as I'm not sure if the issues were just related to my pair or not. I had the following issues.from 100% battery one of the earbuds lasted 4hours 15minutes on a flight. (no where near the 7 hours it said). this is the main reason I'm returning them.additional problems, when paired with two devices the left earbud kept cutting out intermittently (maybe to do with using ldac on both devices?),occasionally I would notice an earbud would connect to my phone even when in the case in my pocket (they were perfectly clean, lint was not the reason).Lastly to nit pick, the lid on the case was wobbly and felt cheap compared to other headphones.

So far the headphones seem OK. It's too bad I paid "new" prices for obviously used headphones.. on initial connect they had already been named "dudnew" and in its pairing history it already was connected to another phone.
Compared to the Samsung buds I used previously, I do not see why all the hype.  Sound is similar and the Sony do not stay secure as long.  Samsung wins.

These buds sounded OK,I bought without testing.I bought these after seeing online reviews of how good they are.I had to return after one week because I could not get them to stay in my ears, tried all ear piece sizes and settled with the smallest ones but still no luck keeping them in place.I watched lsony vids on how to keep in ears but no luck.If they would have stayed in my ears no problem keeping them.Thanks to Amazon for accepting my return.I will look at Bose because most reviewers state no problem keeping them in place.

Amazing Active Noise Cancelling, as described. Cannot be beat. Sound is absolutely phenmomenal. They hurt your ears if you have smaller ears. Too much pressure in canal and not ergonomic enough. Hurt your ears after 1 hour so their battery life doesn't matter whatsoever if you can't wear them. Left side would cut out and lose connection randomly, would recover eventually. Better options out there for less $$
Noise canceling disappointing,  the app is less than desirable.

reviewTitle: Great sound quality, but too many deal breakers for me
reviewDescription: Here are my honest, frank and down to earth thoughts about these earbuds as a music producer and music lover who has tested more than 50 pairs of earbuds in the past 6 or 7 years:Size of case: Excellent! Much smaller than the XM4 and now finally similar in compactness to competing products.Size of buds: Much smaller, but still stick out a lot on me and look a bit funny - not my favourite physical form of the various buds on the market.Comfort: Really good when stationary, especially now that we have extra small tips. Bad when running. They are top heavy, as all of the weight is above the ear tip, meaning that when running, G-force pulls the device down with every step and that leverage tries to pull them out, creating a noise with every step. Buds which have their centre of mass below the tip, like Airpods Pro and 1More Comfobuds for example, do better in this regard.Sound: Excellent, acoustically speaking, and very enjoyable when stationary, but for me they are completely unusable for running, or even walking, because of the occlusion effect ; the extra loud thud that accompanies each step. This is a problem on many earbuds which fully or partially seal the ear canals, but it's especially terrible on these - the worst I've ever experienced.  Music and podcasts are drowned out by the super loud thuds from my steps. If you listen to your buds at a very loud volume you will probably not mind the thuds. You will also be on Google in 10 years, desperately searching for a cure to your life altering tinnitus, of which there isn't.Codecs:  They don't support AptX Low Latency or any AptX codec for that matter.  So when pairing them to an aptX Bluetooth transmitter there is significant lag between the visual and the audible, so I can't use them to practice piano or work on video and music projects.Wind reduction: A little worse than AirPods Pro 2, but they're both barely tolerable when riding a bike into wind.  It's now no longer a setting in the app, it's just automatic.  They don't come close to the superb wind reduction mode on 1MORE earbuds.ANC: Really good, though I feel they are cheating, as the seal of the deeper penetrating tips (compared to Airpods Pro and some others) are doing a lot more of the work than on other buds. It's easier to create the effect of really good active noise cancelling when the passive noise isolation is doing so much of the work already.  It's like wearing foam earplugs in that respect; of course they are going to reduce noise quite well, but that doesn't mean it's the ANC tech doing anything impressive.Transparency: Super disappointing. My $65 2 year old 1More Comfobuds Pro have better transparency, and sound more like I'm not wearing anything than the Sony's do. Airpods Pro 1 are several years old and have much better transparency. Airpods Pro2 are leaps ahead. The audio quality of the transparency (or Ambient mode as Sony calls it) is ok, but the problem is that it's too quiet and so I sound a bit 'trapped in my own head' and as if I'm slightly deaf.  There is also more hiss than on competing products. It's still far from Apple's transparency, unfortunately, and most surprisingly it's even below some budget buds like the above mentioned ones. If only that ambient slider would go up another 20% to match the volume of the real environment it would be much better, but then the hiss would be even louder and so perhaps that's why Sony turned it down, for fear of people complaining about the hiss.On the bright side, while Sony does not advertise this or even mention it anywhere, these buds have the same hearing-protecting feature that Apple calls "adaptive transparency" on the Airpods Pro 2.  This instantly reduces the volume of sudden loud sounds, like a hammer hitting a plank of wood or a chainsaw.  No one is talking about this, but having tested this I can confirm that it's there.Touch controls: I hate them. You have to tap FOUR times to increase the volume one level. So adjusting the volume requires an incredible amount of tapping, which causes a really loud, deep thud in the ear and pressure against the ear drums. Four unpleasant thuds per level-increase means a dozen thuds right into your ear drum just to go up or down 3 levels, which makes changing the volume something I just don't want to do, opting to reach for my phone instead. There is a section in the app that fools you into thinking it will let you change the taps, but it really doesn't at all. It only lets you swap the left ear with the right ear in terms of which ear controls ANC/Ambient and which controls the music. There's no way to change the number of taps assigned to a given action - you are stuck with the assignments Sony has chosen, which is really, really disappointing and such a waste.Conclusion: Others will love them I'm sure, and that's fantastic, but I am disappointed. The badly implemented and non-customizable touch controls, weak transparency and the worst occlusion of any premium buds I've tried, make them fall far short of my expectations for earbuds at this price.  When a $65 pair of earbuds has better sounding transparency and better controls than a pair 6.6 times their price, something has gone wrong here and I cannot score these any higher than 3 out of 5.  There are earbuds available for less money that are more comfortable, sound pretty much as good acoustically, have a much better thought out control system, much better transparency and are actually useable when walking and running.  I'm amazed Sony is able to charge $130 more than their biggest competition (AirPods Pro 2) whilst giving worse performance in most of the important areas.  Even the charging case feels cheap and creaky.

If it weren't for having the FXM4s, I'd rate this the best TWS product out there.  However, the 4s did have the advantage in 2 areas - better bass/low-end warmth, and better ANC.  I've A/B'd them extensively.  BUT, the new FXM5s have several advantages - form and fit being number one.  Secondly?  The stock sound profile is absolutely incredible - and offers more an "audiophile" tuning profile than the warm, fuller XM4s do.  This is not a bad thing - in fact, it's so good - I can't use the GEQ that comes with the new connect app - the stock sound is outstanding.Are they worth the price?  Not if you own the XM4s.  If you managed to see the once-in-a-while 20% discount?  More than likely yes.  If you truly love incredible sound and detail and clarity and precision in TWS format??  Most certainly yes.  The sound and new form make up for all other discrepancies.Note:  Batteries are draining equally between buds, no issues there.  Connect app works seamlessly.  They sound amazing - but they come at a price and they're not perfect.  Yet.

reviewTitle: By far the best headphones I have used.
reviewDescription: The Sony WF-1000XM5 earbuds blend sleek design with stellar noise cancellation, making a strong statement in the market. While they boast impressive battery life and a comfortable fit, some may find the bass and call quality a tad underwhelming. A few reported connection dropouts hint at room for improvement, yet, the overall balance of aesthetics and performance makes these buds a worthy contender for your ears' affection.

I got burned with the XM4s, they died in a year.Unfortunately the competition is still no match so fingers crossed they got the battery life sorted out.  Thus far they sound amazing.  Rtings tested bass response to be spot on but treble to be slightly lacking, so a slight bump up to 16k in the eq and you're grooving at reference more or less.
Great sounding earbuds. Battery life is very good and excellent noise cancelling. They are a very secure comfortable fit. Won’t disappoint

Sleek design, packed with features, and fantastic sound quality. Best implementation of ANC I've seen yet. The foam ear tips can take some time to break in and may not be for everyone. As a package it's almost worth the eye watering price tag. I whole heartedly recommend them if you can get them for at least 100 dollars off.

TBH, no problem with them so far. Except one of the earbuds switch modes by itself, just going to return and get a new pair. overall pretty good earbuds for gym. I was surprised they don't fall out my ears.

reviewTitle: Excellent quality, well built, will recommend.
reviewDescription: Will buy again

I loved the xm4 so much that i bought 2 pairs and when these came out i was interested. First impressions were good but the glossy plastic was a problem i fixed with Scotch Brite to make it matte and grippy. Then i got silicone eartips since i prefer the ease of insertion over fiddling with the foam tips. After these 2 mods they were really comfortable to wear even tough i had no problems with the big xm4s. Sound wise its quite similar to the xm4s but slightly higher mids and deeper bass. Treble is brighter too and not as layed back as the old version. ANC is also stronger against low rumbles like a/c or loud cars so its easy to fall asleep with these on.
Best head phones I've ever had. Noise cancelling works good at my machining job. No wind noise on my bike and they stay in my ears. Had Galaxy buds before and these are 100 times better.
Great price for a superb product

I bought them, used them for 3 weeks, and returned back.I had WF-1000XM4 earbuds, but since my right bud had issues with the battery (now it lasts for only 15 mins, wearers left lasts for 6 hours still after 1.5 years in use)New ones did not have issues with battery at least for those 3 weeks of usage, but unfortunately, they had super unstable Bluetooth connection. I tried both codecs available as options, both worked really badly. For example, I could not walk and listen to music, since the connection was constantly cutting. The only way I could listen to music uninterruptible - have my phone out of pocket (!!!???)Walk outside and talk was another nightmare, my recipient did not hear my words properly so I needed to shout (M4 did have similar issues, but at least it was doable due to a stable connection)I have no clue how those bloggers were testing these earbuds and let them be "best of 2023" - my experience was horrible as I used them as "walkman"On the bright side: noise cancellation and music quality were on the next level indeed, can't even argue here, but mobility is not something that can be even close to being good.

I was considering these vs the Bose Quiet Comfort 2.  I went with the Sonys because professional reviews were consistently higher.  My only issue with these earbuds is with fitting them.  They have a slightly deformed round shape (ie they're almost symmetrical) so i found it difficult to determine how i should position them in my ears; i could actually fit them having them rotated in a variety of positions, none of which were particularly comfortable and none of which generated that "aha" moment of finding the right position.  I also did not find the instructions very helpful.So i returned them and ordered the Bose.  For me it was night and day.  The fit was much better and determining how to position them was easier because the shape of the buds makes it obvious how they should be positioned.  Plus the Bose instructions on fitting are far superior.  Plus Bose not only has interchangeable tips but also another interchangeable part to optimize the fit for your outer ear.  And finally, they have a built in test you can take to determine if the earbud is properly fitted for your ear.If the Sonys fit you then they could be a 4-5 star product, but my experience was very poor based on the fit alone.

The good. Noise cancelling featuresThe bad. The battery is terrible , both the case and headphones need to be charged constantly. Touch features are way too sensitive , any slight movements or wind sets them off. The price is insane ? I was expecting way more at this price point , I previously had a set of xm3's and absolutely loved them but had them stolen at work so  I needed a replacement ...
They sound great but in comparison to other brands (especially Samsung pro buds 2) I can't say anything else good.

reviewTitle: Problems used to be in the xm4, carried on to xm5
reviewDescription: 1.Momentarily disconnection from either ear abruptly.2.Battery life roughly the same.3.Medium ear tip too small but large ear tip too large.4.The slippery finish on the side is almost anti-human design, you'll never pick it up in the first try.

reviewTitle: can't get a seal ..  my XM4's do !
reviewDescription: Too bad they didn't incorporate a second attachment option as these will not fit my ears.  I was excited but now I'm returning and hope my XM4's last.  I may have to switch to bose next .  I love my XM4's ..I feel Sony should have tested the fit on more ears .  I tried all the tips.. multiple,multiple times .

Noise cancelling works as long as these earbuds are snuffed into your earholes real tight. They tend to rely more of passive noise cancelling rather than active noise cancelling. Even when using the largest available ear foams that came with it and plugged in my earbuds until it hurts, it will tend to get loosened on its own, then noise cancelling isn't as effective as it should be. This happens too often that I think these buds are just not meant for me. I've read that I'm not the only one who encounters this. It is a common problem. There I conclude that noise cancelling on this thing is not as good as what the reviews say online.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2023
reviewDescription: I've used many different brands of earbuds, and for the price, these are probably the worst I've used, to a degree I'm struggling to comprehend. Let's get one thing out of the way: they sound good. It's better than my AirPods Pro 2s. Everything else, and I mean everything else, is so much worse. Let's start at the top.These things are so slippery that I struggle to get them out of the case without dropping them. And for me, the shape is hard to get into my ears. Also, the case feels cheap. They charge $300 for these?Setup is a chore. You are required to use the app to access any of its features. And boy, is it a piece of work. From opening the app to first listening to anything took just over an hour. AN HOUR! You must log into a Sony account to get most of the high-end features to work, which is nonsense. And lord help you if you had a Playstation account 15 years ago. I appreciate the trouble Sony has gone to for security, but I had to do a 10-part captcha from hell twice to get into the account. And the translation to English in the app is poor at best, making the whole experience a head-scratching mess. The device pairing process is easy, however.The noise canceling is about as good as my 70-dollar no-name Chinese buds. Seems better at high-pitched things than general background noise, which is a strange feat as the former is much harder to pull off. I struggle to hear dogs barking, but my AC is as clear as a bell. The ambient pass-through is barely acceptable, not even in the same league as the AirPod Pros. Your voice tends to be over-amplified and slightly delayed, making talking to and understanding others a mess. The feature that mutes whatever you are listening to and turns off ANC when you start talking is hit or miss. It works about half the time when I start talking. The other half kicks on when any noise is picked up. Very annoying.Now, the reason I purchased these is Multipoint Bluetooth. This feature lets devices connect to multiple devices simultaneously and quickly switch between them. It's crucial for any work that has you bouncing between phone calls and working on a PC. Let me tell you, Sony's implementation is worse than useless. Can I connect to two devices? Sure. Can I stay connected to two devices? Absolutely not. When they are connected, does it switch seamlessly between the two? Also, absolutely not. If one is already making a sound, the other device can't be changed without silencing the first device. So, say you are listening to YouTube on your PC and get a call. To switch to the call, pause YouTube and anything else making sound, then answer the call. And about 50% of the time, it will switch. Otherwise, you have to change it manually. What is even the point? Even more fun is that the second device can't be switched to after some time, between 5 minutes and who knows how long, without manually going into settings and reconnecting first. Then you get another 5 minutes to a couple of hours of flaky "fast switching".The battery life is an actual lie. They claim 8 hours, but with all features turned off except playback, I got closer to 6. With ANC on, I may have gotten 4-5 hours. Each bud's battery seems to drain at different speeds as well. So, while one may have 10% left, the other is already dead.I would be less critical if these were $100 instead of $300. Crucially, though, even at $100, I would still return them. Other than sounding great, they are terrible to use. And for $100, I can get earbuds that sound just as good but aren't so finicky.In closing, I'm surprised Sony released such a poor product. They're so bad that it's tarnished my view of the company.

reviewTitle: Not as good as previous generation.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2023
reviewDescription: While these are smaller, they are not better. I own the previous generation Sony 1000XM4 noise canceling ear buds, but unfortunately the right ear bud battery was dying after 2ish years of near constant use.Lucky me, or so I though, this new version released. I was excited they were smaller as I sleep with them to distract me from wife snoring, and my over thinking mind racing as I try to sleep.These ear buds suck.First, they're slick. Like, slippery when not wet. They're a pain to manipulate because the entire outer surface is a shiney black plastic. Going in the case, coming out the case, fitting the correctly to your ear. God forbid you drop one and have to grab it.Second, the previous generation has far better noise canceling. Putting those in was like tuning out the world. These XM5's won't tune out my wife's relatively low volume snoring on the best of nights. If I'm sleeping with one ear bud pointed away, or covered, from her side of the bed, the noise canceling does not work at all. Snoring comes through loud and clear, even over the noise I listen to to fall asleep. This was not an issue on the previous version. I had no issues sleeping on my side, or not pointing both ear buds in her direction to get adequate noise canceling. Obvious stuff gets through when it shouldn't.Third, and most annoying, the touch sensitivity on these things is insane. Not only will the briefest of brushes of the hand either pause what your listening to, or turn off noise cancelling, but so can your pillow case or any other fabric that brushes them. Sometimes activating multiple times in a single touch. Again, this was never an issue in the previous version. The only way to fix this is to turn the feature off entirely, making you wholely dependent on your phone to control playback or noise canceling functionality.I've been a big fan of Sony's noise cancelling for years now. I genuinely think it's the best in the business. But these headphones should be a hard pass for anyone looking to buy.Trust me when I say this: save yourself some money and buy the previous generation if you can find them. They are slightly bigger, but they are by far the better product and can be found cheaper.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2023
reviewDescription: I was in the market for some ear buds that had noise cancellation while on phone calls. These were the highest rated online. THEY WERE FAR FROM THE BEST! For starters, setup with iOS would have been easier if Sony had a better app. The app crashed a couple times during the setup process due to it trying to update the ear buds firmware. Once I got past that I was able to dive into the settings within the app for the ear buds. There were many settings and nothing out of the ordinary. The feature to connect 2 devices at once via Bluetooth was nice. However the noise cancellation feature itself was sub-par. Even after trying all of the different size buds that came with the product and performing the in app test to make sure I had the correct fit. Noise Cancellation while on a phone call was good for the caller on the other end. But the disappointment to me was when I had the ear buds in, not playing anything with noise cancellation on. It would muffle the outside noise but not cancel it. I was as if I simply had ear plugs in. For that reason I returned them. The body of the ear bud was also large and heavy which caused it to fall out of my ear when simply walking. I've had AirPod Pros, Beats Fit Pro's and these Sony WF-1000XM5. AirPod Pros had better noise cancellation ability then these. The winner for me was the Beats Fit Pro.

reviewTitle: Defective after two weeks, no support available.
reviewDescription: These are almost great earbuds. The noise cancellation is some of the best I've seen, they're very well constructed and feel premium (appropriate considering the $200+ price tag), and the sound quality is perfectly acceptable.Unfortunately, they're also the least pleasant headphones to actually interact with I've ever owned. All three sizes of earbud tips failed to stay secure in my ears, so I was constantly stopping what I was doing to nudge them back into place. This isn't helped by the fact that the touch controls are wildly inconsistent. A double touch plays and pauses the audio, and a long touch toggles the noise cancellation options, so while trying to push them back into your ear you're almost always going to be accidentally triggering a function and then having to tap again to undo it. These are also annoying to make work on purpose, sometimes requiring four or five double taps to actually play/pause.There's also something about the design of these that make them uniquely hard to hold. I've used wireless earbuds for years now, and I've never had issues with dropping them. The contour on the sides of these earbuds are sloped in such a way that it's impossible to hold them with any pressure, so you're always at risk of them slipping or popping out of your fingers when you pull them out of the case. I dropped one into traffic within the first few days. Thankfully managed to retrieve it with seemingly zero damage.Then one day (about two weeks after receiving them) the right earbud's volume was suddenly so low that I couldn't always tell it was powered on at all. I contacted support, thinking that there would be some kind of reset button or cleaning instructions. Nope, request a refund on Amazon. They wouldn't even talk to me, and there's no support documentation available. I would seriously recommend you look at some of the hundreds of less frustrating, much cheaper options on the market for bluetooth earbuds. I'm going back to my $60 pair of Raycons and honestly looking forward to it.

Malheureusement retourné apres 10 jours car produit pas au point: Impossible de changer les parametres dans l'application fournie avec l'appareil et qui permet de changer L'ANC notamment.Nombreux interlocuteurs n'entendent pas bien ma voix lorsque je parle au téléphone malgré les 6 micros?Service à la clientele Nul comme dans zero retour ou meme accusé réception. Apres 10 jours de taponnage dans l'application, je suis retourné à mon oreillette à 25$ qui elle fonctionne sans probleme. Coté écoute musicale, le produit est cependant irréprochable

After losing my 1more ColorBuds, which I loved, I wanted to love these, but I don't think I do. The sound is not as full, and the vocals are up front in the mix. The controls are a bit finicky and they're also quite slippery. I dunno, maybe I'll just get another pair of ColorBuds. I was expecting to be blown away by these.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2022
reviewDescription: I'm not a super audio nerd, but I've dealt with music all my life and worked in radio broadcasting, sound editing, mixing, composing, producing, and other stuff for over a few decades. I know what "good" sound is, for different uses & scenarios.After researching lists of best bluetooth earbuds, these popped up highly on a few well scouted lists. Ordered them, and almost immediately the trouble began.First off - the app. Completely useless. I'm sure it's probably abandoned by now, it refused to get past the "can't see your device" screen for 4 different devices I tried to connect it to. It would hook up to Bluetooth just fine, but app wouldn't work at all. Not one time. Chatbot help was in Chinese. No manual in the box, not even a QR code scan thing. No warranty info. Normally I wouldn't care so much, but without being able to check or toggle them in LDAC mode was very frustrating. There's no reason the app shouldn't work. Also, I read there is no in-app manual EQ. Anything that wants to even begin to think of calling itself "audiophile", needs to start from there with its app. Inexcusable if it's not in there.Second, the fit (for me personally) was very subpar. They come with different silicone tips, but the largest size & smallest size aren't that different, and if you put real quality foam tips on them it improves a lot, but then they won't fit back into the case. They never felt like they were "in" my ear all the way making a good seal. I always wanted to fiddle with them. This of course depends on your anatomy. The active noise canceling however did work a little, and had 3 noticeable different modes - ambient sound, off, and on. Figured that out randomly by tapping the earbud 3 times. Almost like that's something that should be explained in an included manual or something.Third - and most important (and subjective), the sound. They were...fine. Average. Nothing amazing in my opinion, and far far short of all the gleaming recommendations I've read. For headphones, some of my experiences go from MDR V-700S, HDJ-1000s & AT M50xs for spinning records, 7506s, HD280s & Fidelio X2HRs for editing, Bose qc35s & WH1000 XM2s for over ear Bluetooth headphones, to Google pixel buds series A & Shure SE215s for Bluetooth in-earbuds to name just some.In direct comparison, the pixel buds A sound a little better, fit a little better, have an actual usable app & great Google integration, and are almost $50 cheaper (give or take, depending on sales) than the Evos.In a completely different league though, are the Shure se215s. These things (to me) are probably the best pick you can get for affordable bluetooth IEMs. They fit well with good 3rd party eartips, and sound incredible, especially for the price. The sound stage is wide yet isolated, separation and distinction is great, bass is deep & booming & punchy but not muddy, and bright, wide, non-harsh highs. They're 5 times the headphones the 1more Evos are. Plus, they're usually under 100$. They're worth 3 times that, easy.I could go on and nit pick more about other little things, but my point is made. They're just not worth it to me. Audio is such a unique, personal thing, that these may sound & fit amazing to you, and you'll think I'm crazy. This is just how my ears hear them. I'm very very disappointed, but these are going back.
I just can't recommend it, I have like second pair that isn't functioning properly. Software is lacking so much features

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
reviewDescription: Got these back on October 19th of this year. They worked great at first. Then today they would not disconnect from my phone when I put them in the charging case (fully charged). If I went to Bluetooth settings and manually disconnected them they'd disconnect for a few seconds before they were connected again. I downloaded a volume booster app to see if they'd play music while in the case. Had that at max boost nothing then when I took one out of the case I could hear the music from an arm's length away. After removing from case my phone said that their battery charge had increased. I thought it might've been my phone acting up so I restarted it nope that didn't fix it. I I selected in the Bluetooth settings of my phone to forget the 1more evo. Not connected yay. I then tried to repair them to my phone they are not showing up. And this is only 39 days after receiving them. I would be returning them if I could.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 13, 2023
reviewDescription: I had to return these as they would pair okay with my Android phone but seemed to have a lot of issues when trying to pair with a Windows laptop so be aware if you want to use with Windows based devices. It's a shame as they sounded reasonable for the price.

estaba muy ilusionado con estos auriculares y la verdad es que se escuchan genial pero pierden la señal de audio y cada vez que los pruebo mas lo hacen, y ya los devolvere ya no me atrevo a repetir por que a otro cliente de amazon le paso parecido

reviewTitle: Volume dropped to almost inaudible in about six months.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2023
reviewDescription: I bought these to replace old Raycons after some research and was hopeful that I would get a lot of use out of these. I like that the app lets you customize the sound profiles, and the battery life is good. They also have a very sleek appearance and feel. However, after six months the volume rapidly started to drop. Very quiet even at max volume, with crunchy static sounds even with ANC turned off.The only way to do a warranty replacement - which you're entitled to within a year - is to email them, according to their website. I've emailed them twice with no response over the past several weeks. I have to wonder if anyone is even monitoring that email at all. Pretty bummed overall. Back to wired earbuds for the meantime.

reviewTitle: Overall Good Headphones that Died 13 Months Later
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2023
reviewDescription: Generally nothing really bad here.  Sound is good, audio app is decent, if a bit annoying.  Controls require too many taps for some features (even though there is a degree of programmability), but after a recent FW update the right bud noise is low and it clearly isn't doing any cancelling...1 month outside the warranty period.  Cleaned them thoroughly and did a reset on the buds, but no joy.  I expect more than e-waste 13 months after a purchase.

6 months in and these no longer work. Right side is either blown or just does not work. Left side sounds as if it is playing music from down a very long hallway. I would give these 4 stars based on how they performed in the first 5 months of use. You definitely needed to use the sound ID to shape your ideal experience. But they had a nice deep and fairly round Soundstage. But 6 months later they are useless. No sound from the right side and the left is not great either( they are connecting and pairing well, though). These are my second (and last) pair of 1more headphones to leave me underwhelmed and disappointed.

reviewTitle: Worst connectivity issues I've ever had.
reviewDescription: The earbuds want to connect to Bluetooth one at a time. Which makes each earbuds output 1 second off from eachother. This throws the earbuds off and makes them stop connecting for a few seconds then reconnect, disconnect reconnect etc. it's taken everything in my being not to whip these down the street. I've now swapped back to using my wired earbuds as these are utter garbage. Safe your money and buy AirPods if you want Bluetooth earbuds.

reviewTitle: En panne après quelques mois d’utilisation
reviewDescription: Utilisé en kit mains libres et écoute musique quotidienne. Dommage qu’ils ne soit pas fiable car la qualité du son était bonne et les discussions naturelles au début.Maintenant on m’entend comme dans une cave et une oreillette ne fonctionne plus.Dommage

Ich kann zu den technischen Dingen eigentlich wenig sagen, aber eine Kaufwarnung aussprechen damit andere Menschen die Pads von z.B. Comply nutzen einen weiten Bogen um dieses Gerät machen: mit anderen Pads als den mitgelieferten geht weder das Ladecase zu noch berühren sich die Kontakte zum laden. Wer designt diese Dinger? Wer kommt auf die Idee, wenn ich hochwertige Memory Foam Pads nutze, um den gesamten Dynamikumfang der ansonsten klanglich sehr guten Hörer ausreizen zu können, dass man vor und nach jedem ins Ladetui stecken die Pads an- oder abomontieren will / soll?!? Völlig unbegreiflich. Mit den mitgelieferten Standardpads sind die Kopfhörer klanglich sehr reduziert und entsprechen dem Preis nicht wirklich. Ein Jammer.

reviewTitle: problème de son et pas de piece de remplacement
reviewDescription: Quand les écouteurs marchent ils sont tres bien.mais j'ai eu un problème ou un écouteur avait un son plus faible voir aucun son. ce problème apparaissait 1 fois tout les 2 jours. Le support n'a pas réussi a résoudre mon problème en 3 semaine d'echanges de mail.Je viens de perdre l'etuit de chargement et le support me dit qu'il n'y a aucun moyen de le remplacer (meme en payant)

reviewTitle: The hype for these are completely unjustified
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2022
reviewDescription: First off the 1More app, it's awful. Running the app on my S22 Ultra it constantly force closes, has issues connecting to the earbuds, firmware updating within the app failed multiple times.Second the buds themselves, also awful. Out of the box they're incredibly staticy and sound subpar. This is with LDAC enabled/disabled so don't believe the "Grammy award winning" tuning mumbo jumbo. Why is there no eq????? The touch controls are crap there is a 1-2 second delay before the touch controls register in popular apps like YouTube, YouTube music etc. The volume + & - touch controls don't work. Why can't I customize the touch controls individually???? Transparency mode only works with both buds in your ears and it's barely noticeable when enabled. Anc is a joke. Covering my ears with hands works miles better than the anc on these things it's seriously a joke. The oval shaped tips don't stay in no matter what and you can feel when the "seal" slips.I have nothing to say about the multi point capability which I'm sure is also a joke. I packed these up in 30 mins and will be returning them. These are supposed to be premium yet they function like cheap $50 earbuds. The legit only worth while feature about these buds is the case. The case feels substantial and has a nice anti slip surface on the bottom. Wireless charge works fine.I have tried and own many wireless earbuds from various manufacturers and I can say this is the first time I legit hate a pair of buds. Avoid these.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 31, 2023
reviewDescription: I recently purchased the 1MORE EVO earbuds with high expectations. However, I must say I'm disappointed. The right earbud is clearly defective, as its battery drains much faster than the left earbud. It dropped to zero percent while the left earbud still had 80 percent battery after approximately 110 minutes (tested three times with music playing, no ANC, and LDAC off). I've tried charging them fully, but the problem persists.I have lost confidence in 1MORE, as I have bought three earbuds from them. The first one only lasted one year, the second one couldn't charge or pair, and now the third one, which is the 1MORE EVO, has this battery issue. I'll be returning them to Amazon for a refund.

reviewTitle: Placed order brand new and got 2nd hand
reviewDescription: The photos are too obvious. Even the right ear bud almost no sound with maximum volume.
Ils sont excellents mais le droit ne fonctionne déjà plus (et ils n'ont pris aucun choc)

reviewTitle: Falla en 6 meses, no lo recomiendo.
reviewDescription: El producto en si es tal cual se describe, bonito, con calidad de materiales, con calidad de sonido, pero en 6 meses el auricular derecho solo dura cargado 20 minutos. He enviado mensajes al servicio de atención al cliente de 1MORE y no recibo ninguna respuesta.Al menos Amazon me ha respondido, devuelvo el producto y me abonan el dinero.

reviewTitle: Great sound for a very small package
reviewDescription: (take it with a grain of salt)(Tried with an iPhone it works fine with all its features) (Review is subject to change as updates rolls in)May 20: I have been having issues with the earphones cutting out randomly when using LDAC (in adaptive mode), a distance from my head to my pocket shouldn't really cause any issues and I know this is not due to interference because I have been in a park for 6 hours and it would cut out still, not to mention that I also did an audiophile session where I just sat on a chair and listened to my favourite tracks while the phones is on the table next to me so range is also not an issue I believe. This issue should be fixed as soon as they can.A gust of wind is very audible through ANC and Transparent mode.ANC: It could be better, I would say Apple's ANC is a bit better but this isn't that far behind in my opinion.
